Consent:
Welcome to the UKRN Survey on Open and Transparent Research Practices


This survey is open to those based at a UK HE institution which has a UKRN Institutional Lead. Its purpose is to establish what the level and perception of Open and Transparent Research Practices are at these institutions. The results of this survey will be used to provide insight into the open research practices that are used and recognised/rewarded across disciplines and institutions. The results will also help identify training gaps. We are interested in gathering responses about both Quantitative AND Qualitative research practices. Additionally, we are interested in responses from both those who already use open research practices, and those that do not. Usual time to complete the survey is under 20 minutes. 



The practices are defined as those in the FORRT Community-Sourced Glossary of Open Scholarship Terms. We chose this standard due to differences in how some terms are used across disciplines. The survey focuses on 14 core topics in the research lifecycle. Definitions for each of these topics are also informed by the FORRT glossary.



The insights of the survey will be shared on an institutional level and as an aggregated UKRN-wide report. Data is collected anonymously. You have the chance to enter a prize draw to win one of ten (per institution) Â£50.00 Amazon vouchers (we will collect personal information should you decide to take part in the prize draw. This data is not linked to your survey responses to safeguard your anonymity).



Survey responses will inform the implementation of open research practices and training at UKRN institutions. Therefore, it is important for all views to be represented. You are encouraged to take part whether or not you are aware of open research practices, and whether or not you deem them relevant or necessary for your field of research. Your participation will ensure that related guidance developed at departmental/institutional and/or UKRN-wide level is appropriate for your discipline. 



The survey was approved by the University of Manchester Ethics Review Panel (Ref: 2022-15389-26232) and the Participant Information Sheet can be found by clicking on this link.

Q5: Phase 2: Early (e.g., Research Associate, first grant holder, Lecturer)
Q1.9: Asked a mentor at the institution I previously worked at.
Q1.13: Reproducibility is increasingly important in my field but not encouraged by journals: replication work doesn't get published easily and, therefore, there is not much incentive for researchers/academics to focus on improving their knowledge of and skill in producing reproducible research/work.
Q3.12: Barriers to conducting qualitative research is GDPR. Ethical guidelines influence what data can be shared, and qualitative data (e.g., interviews, focus group data, passages of text) are, in my opinion, easier to link to indviduals/to identify than quantitative (aggregate) data.

Q1.13: Some of my research involved surveying community opinion. I do ask some individuals in the community about how this should be done before doing it.
Q2.7_8_TEXT: These questions really hard to answer because I have a totally different approach and opinion about different aspects of this (e.g. ethics vs. GDPR)
Q2.12: GDPR etc is OK (I broadly approve of the law, and local implementation is sometimes annoying but OK) but ethics is a total nightmare at my institution. My UREC has attempted to destroy my most recent study by retrospectively withdrawing permission for it. They are totally out of step with the research community (I know many other colleagues who regard our UREC as incompetent and dictatorial). Research ethics as implemented at Oxford Brookes goes against basic conceptions of morality and has almost nothing to do with Open Science.
Q3.1: I am not aware of this
Q4.12: It requires time but is necessary
Q5.12: Again, takes time but is very necessary
Q5.13: I think this is ones of the hardest areas to get right. Gold standards of pre-registration are often too hard to meet and I think there needs to be be more discussion, publication, and training about compromises. Just one example: it's often impossible for me to not have given data some preliminary examination (e.g. calculate some basic descriptives) prior to pre-registration. I believe some forms of pre-registration could still be valid (e.g. if I haven't yet tested any hypotheses, it could still be valid to pre-register hypotheses after some preliminary knowledge of descriptive information) but there is little out there to guide on this.
Q6.12: Occasionally free software is poorly documented.
Q6.13: The authors of software like R and Blender are the unsung heroes of the modern age.
Q8.12: This is hard to get right. I write software, I code in many languages, I have accounts on GitHub etc, but I find the standard approaches to version control counter-intuitive and tutorials hard to follow..
Q12.13: This has been one of the issues I have had with my ethics committee. They seem to think the fact that I care about the environment and have some opinions about solutions means I have a conflict of interest situation when researching the psychology of this.

Q3.12: The biggest risks fall on researchers from underrepresented groups - being transparent opens up researchers to useful skills and inforamtion sharing, but also to predatory credit-takers.
Q3.13: There is little requirement for researchers to be transparent/open/reproducible or and most researchers are overworked/stressed out so are unlikely to give themselves more work to learn a skill set that is not required.

Q5: Phase 4: Established/Experienced (e.g., Professor, Principal Fellows or Scientists)
Q1.12: our research is essentially multi-disciplinary and frequently internationally linked. The risk of losing EU collaboration is a major barrier/risk
Q1.13: collaboration has to be learned; I am not fond of training programs in this domain (personal opinion)
Q2.12: We are very active in patenting and spinning out biotech companies. Disclosing even ideas for innovative approaches too early is a major risk for this ambition.
Q2.13: We prefer to develop certain ideas using VC money rather than institutional support (MRC, WT...) in order to avoid getting copied
Q3.12: risks and opportunities: we are developing new technologies and validating them
Q3.13: important; not sure it can be taught as a general field - risks to be too non-specific
Q4.12: We are working in UK's most digitally mature Trust and have a whole BRC Theme devoted to Advanced Health Informatics. The problem is not so much training, it's scarcity of educated people in the field who are willing to work for an academic salary
Q4.13: high importance; new university structures/education pathways required to tackle it comprehensively. Training programs can help but not categorically change the void
Q5.12: I really do not know what you mean! There are so many types of protocols. If we develop f.e. protocols for new drugs/clinical trials we are obliged to register them with eg MHRA but they have proprietary character and are NOT publicly shared. If we develop research protocols eg to enable single base pair editing these involve proprietary know-how and will/have to be fully QCed but will NOT be shared in the public domain. I am aware that you may be asking with a view to other fields but your questions are too non-specific.
Q6.12: open-source tools are important in eg genomics in all its applications, as algorithms in health informatics and in population health studies etc. In fact they are very different, very specified tools. Again, your questions are not specified enough.
Q7.12: this is a very specific question that only applies to a fraction of our researchers; for them it is evidently important
Q8.12: I guess you are asking this question from an IT point of view: very important; but keep in mind that this is also a very important question for eg GMP production of drugs (which we are involved in). It is the basis of every QC process and indispensable
Q9.12: All research has to be reproducible! This is not reserved to computational research. Where research involves computing processes of course they need to be reproducible.
Q10.12: no risks; it has to be a given
Q11.12: contribution is qualified in appraisals, in research output (authorship, inventorship etc) and in other various ways. We make sure students and young researchers are empowered by integrating them into our decision-making panels. The major risk I see is in sticking to outdated academic hierarchical systems.
Q12.12: CoIs need to be declared; and managed well; they SHOULD NOT preclude PIs from working in a given field as has recently been done by UCL admin f.e. for PIs with an active role both on the UCL and Trust side
Q12.13: The UCL Conflict of Interest paper has grown into a lawyer thesis with the downside of lacking clear applicability
Q13.12: Academics are usually reasonably smart. You don't need to train for the obvious (unless you are a training freak)
Q14.12: same point: no need to train; the institutions are all pushing for open access (NIHR even forcing) but at the same time not providing the financial resources necessary. It is a feasibility issue, not a training problem
Q16_11_TEXT: as outlined: besides some of the points above such as lack of dedicated funding one major consideration is that where PI/inventions/critical know-how is involved the interest to make this data widely available at an early stage is minimal

Q5: Phase 3: Mid/Recognised (e.g., Senior Lecturer, Reader, Senior Researcher)
Q1.12: No - it's just not relevant.  I study the open ocean, and there are no local communities to co-produce with.
Q1.13: I study the open ocean, and so there are no local communities or stakeholders to co-produce with.  This is fundamental ocean research, of global importance but focussed on the nuts and bolts of climate understanding.
Q2.12: We have to have permission to collect data within national ocean jurisdictions and this is non-negotiable.  We have always had to do it, and it's normal practice.
Q3.9: national websites and relevant national organisations
Q3.13: It's required by the research councils - it's normal practice.
Q5.13: We are a very data-poor field - every single bit of field data is valuable.  We're not going to throw any of it away because we didn't think of a particular idea before data collection.  The ocean is only that way once - on that day, in that location - no-one can ever go back and re-measure it.  Every single bit of data will be stored and used and we cannot possibly limit that by not having thought of the question beforehand.
Q6.9: Whoever is supplying the software I need.
Q6.13: It's more important that the data is open than the software.  We just use whatever software tools we need to do the best science.
Q7.13: I don't have time to write software well enough to share it publicly, but I would share if asked by a colleague - that's normal practice.
Q9.13: I don't know what you mean by "computationally reproducible".  The same data sets will be analysed by others sometimes, but only if someone got funding to re-analyse lots of differnet field data together (which is rare in my field - agencies do not want to fund it)
Q10.9: national agencies and organisations that work on this issue.
Q11.9: journal recommendations and national society/organisation guidelines
Q11.13: conventions are different in different fields and countries (for example, on how/whether to credit technicians) and so it's more dependent on culture than agreed written standards.
Q12.13: Not relevant in my field - there is no commercial interest etc in this.
Q13.13: My field doesn't use pre-prints at all.  Either it's published in a reputable journal or it isn't, but no-one feels any need to produce pre-prints - in this field there don't seem to be any benefits (it's a small field and we all know what everyone is doing and would ask if we needed info).  Also, publishing in open-access open-review journals is becoming more common, so traditional pre-prints are bypassed because the manuscript is immediately online.
Q14.9: national organisations that work on this issue

Q3: (CAH02) Subjects allied to medicine (e.g., nursing, pharmacology, health sciences)
Q5: Phase 2: Early (e.g., Research Associate, first grant holder, Lecturer)
Q1.12: There are many barriers to proper research co-production, primarily budget and timeframes. Proper budgets need to be planned into grants and there needs to be enough time in the project planning for co-production, building relationships with groups etc. and then carrying it out throughout the project. It is often the first thing to be cut.
Q1.13: The timeframes and rigid university structures (around payment in particular) are real barriers.
Q2.7_8_TEXT: It's good but rarely focused on qualitative research which needs a different approach to purely quant research.
Q2.12: It's very challenging to share data openly when the topics are sensitive e.g. violence and abuse. This needs real thought, structures and support to do it.
Q2.13: Open data for qualitative research could transform the field as you'd have access to bigger datasets and could avoid going back to vulnerable populations with the same questions.
Q3.12: Barriers to transparency include lack of understanding of qualitative research at senior levels (often it's a small add-on project to fulfil funder requirements), or the pressure to publish and finish quickly means it gets lost in the process
Q3.13: Transparency is really important and the more good practices can be shared (perhaps around research management in particular) the better
Q4.12: I'm not sure this really exists in qualitative research. I always write protocols and try and pre-register on OSF but I see this rarely in other qualitative work. I have tried to get advice on qualitative data management plans but failed to find anything. It would be great to have protocols and processes to draw on rather than feeling like you have to reinvent the wheel.
Q4.13: Anything from the quant/coding side which could be applied to qualitative data would be great. I use OSF but I think there's scope for it to be better used specifically for qualitative data management. There isn't the time to experiment and work out how to do things so people need protected time to design efficient and helpful workflows, including examples of data management plans that can be used in qualitative studies.
Q5.12: As mentioned before this is not common practice in qualitative research. We are adapting quant-focused processes to qualitative practices and it doesn't always quite work.
Q5.13: There's lots of work to be done in this area to promote qualitative protocol registrations etc.
Q6.12: The standard software used for qualitative research tends to be proprietary (and better supported by universities). I have tried looking for open source options but when you don't have time to try out different options and work out what best suits your needs it's just easier to go with the usual susupects.
Q6.13: There are open source qualitative software options but they're less developed than quantitative options/versions (e.g. compare the number of statistical R packages vs. the one qualitative one)
Q7.12: I just don't think it happens in qualitative research (or very rarely)
Q7.13: I have written code for non-open source software but, particularly within qualitative research, you don't have the time, resources, experience or skills to do this.
Q8.12: The challenge with version control is all the different ways of doing it - again I'd just like there to be one accepted way (probably related to ethics applications) that could just be applied in general. I don't want to have to think about it too much.
Q8.13: This should be standardised, simple and intuitive - my impression is everyone has slightly different ways of doing it which doesn't help.
Q9.12: This doesn't really apply to qualitative research, which is about interpretation. I think transparency is the main issue. I have only done this for (quant) survey analysis. But in that case I didn't know what I was doing or how to make Excel calculations reproducible.
Q9.13: If journals don't ask for it then I don't think people will do it.
Q10.12: I'm not sure how much work has been done specifically applying these principles to qualitative work.
Q10.13: They need adapting for qualitative work.
Q11.13: Like other things I think journals need to require this for people to do it.
Q13.13: Linking up pre-print with final published version isn't always effective so people continue citing the pre-print.
Q14.12: The barrier is funding if it's not part of the grant.
Q14.13: I think it's key for improving access to findings.
Q16_11_TEXT: Lack of adaptation to qualitative research

Q2.13: UCL recently introduced new regulations that are onereous to comply with regarding open source research. Open reseach is already extremely important in my field and we all have a very effective way of making all of our research open source through a strong instiutional culture of posting preprints to arxiv.org. EPSRC's new regulations merely make my job harder and constrain my ability to get my papers accepted at top journals while at the same time having no positive effect on the open source nature of my research.

Q7.12: I don't know what this question means. Are you asking whether e.g. the adoption of open source software would negatively impact me or my community? The answer to all such questions is usually emphatically "no".
Q7.13: Most pure mathematicians are open source evangelists - there is no need for us to be "educated" on the merits of open source software, and any central administration policy to promote the use of open source software would only encumber us and not do any good at all.

Q8.13: Really, version control is not a complicated topic. I don't need anyone to waste my time with extra "training" on this subject, which whould likely be of little value and a waste of my time. I already have a version control system for my academic output in place out of practical necessity and it works fine. Please don't waste my time with extra mandatory trainings.
Q9.13: peer review in my field (pure maths) consists of reproducing the proofs of theorems on the referees part. It is a laborious and long process but is highly valued by my community. I can't imagine any formal training on this topic that would be better than the training that we all get as PhD students in mathematics. Any additional "training" on this topic is unwelcome and unnecessary. Reproducibility is the bread and butter of my subject.
Q10.13: We already do this; I know how to do this; it is highly valued in my community. I do not need any additional training on this topic. I feel that any extra training on this topic would be a waste of time for me when I could be actually doing research instead.

Q1.13: Lab-based biochemistry is difficult to do with citizen science or "co-production", particularly given IP/data regulations for use of data in the university. May be more appropriate in other fields (e.g. healthcare)
Q2.13: GDPR is included in general data storage and Information security in the university and is mandatory training for all staff, with renewal on an annual basis. For my field, very little patient data is used so has not come up in research work so far.
Q3.13: Not aware of direct information from university/department regarding qualitative data practices, only information is what I have sought from sources regarding publishing of unedited data images alongside published manuscripts. Encouraged at lab group level.
Q4.13: Again, I'm aware of practices to make code/original data sets available through actively looking from publishers websites and other stakeholders rather than through institutional/departmental regulations. Occurs at the group level but not widespread.
Q5.13: Not sure if applicable to my field of research when not using publicly available datasets or personal data.
Q6.13: Maybe carried out by computational groups using code (generally using GitHub) to provide open source code. Most software used is commercially available in my field of research so rarely share open code.
Q7.13: I don't do much coding/software creation in my research but other computational groups do. Perhaps this is encouraged at group/sub-group level but unaware of institutional/departmental regulations on this topic.
Q8.13: Done at group/sub-group level on an ad-hoc basis (i.e. dated file names for manuscripts or figures). Noted for publication for version of software used for analysis of data to keep track.
Q9.13: Tried to keep my own data computationally reproducible by re-analysis using same conditions, etc. on a different day/account/software version to check for any variability. This is in addition to experimental/biological repeats for data validation.
Q10.13: I am aware of repositories to use for datasets and original qualitative data images but only through personal research of publishing practice. Not aware of policies at departmental or institutional level. Training could be to point research staff towards areas of good practice and common repositories to use. Likely occurs at group/sub-group level.
Q11.13: Acknowledging who did the work is taken into account for publication of research work. CRediT taxonomy was found through publisher guidelines.
Q12.13: Taken very seriously across research and all working life at the institution. Any conflicts (financial or otherwise) are asked to be disclosed without judgement to ensure transparency in decision making or in motives,
Q13.13: Varies group to group, depending on group leader. Encouraged to have a look over by other PIs in the department before pre-print submission for clarity/written quality.
Q14.13: Taken very seriously at institution level as OA is required by many of the relevant funding bodies in my research field. Often extortionately expensive, particularly for smaller research groups so needs much more financial support for new starting groups.

Q1.13: Only those historians professionally trained with the correct linguistic and palaeographical skills would be able to undertake research in my field
Q2.13: The objects of historical research (archives, documents, texts) are located in repositories that allow access only to professionally-qualified researchers: beyond digitization, they cannot by virtue of their nature become more 'open', and the data I gather from them is in the form of notes, not data-sets that would be meaningful to subsequent scholars
Q3.13: Qualitative research must be transparent to be persuasive in my discipline: if the sources are not presented upon which an argument rests, the argument fails
Q4.13: This issue is becoming an increasingly common question raised by funders in submitting grant applications, but in my discipline it is meaningless: my preparatory notes, handwritten or typed, do not constitute a data set that could be subjected to a management plan
Q6.1: I am not aware of this
Q6.13: My research does not rely on the use of computer software beyond standard packages
Q8.12: The proliferation of different versions of studies, from preliminary submission to author-accepted version to properly type-set and completed publication, generates an unhelpful mass of different versions, over which control cannot be exercised meaningfully, and resulting in scholars without access to the final publication using outdated versions
Q8.13: In the field of history there is no advantage to speedy pre-publication of research results online - the problem of excessive versions could be avoided entirely with an understanding of open access less determined by the practices of the applied sciences
Q9.13: All historical research should be reproducible in the sense that the sources used must be able to be located and scrutinized by others: but so much relies on the intellectual acuity of the historian to interpret those sources analytically that another historian would never come to an exactly identical conclusion, though they should be able to check the validity of the argument
Q10.13: The archival and documentary material on which I work is held by institional repositories and does not become 'mine' through my consultation of it - the issue is consequently irrelevant for my discipline
Q11.13: In History almost all work is single-authored; the issue essentially does not arise
Q12.13: By its nature it is very hard for any aspect of pre-modern history to put any researcher at risk of a conflict of interest
Q13.13: The field of history is not so competitive or fast-paced that pre-prints serve any meaningful purpose; all they contribute is yet another different version of the publication
Q14.12: Open access does present a real risk to the continuing ability of historians to produce their principal contribution, single-authored monographs: if we are required to make our books open access then the main commercial publishers will lose interest, and/or require enormous fees to do so
Q14.13: The significance of open access publication has been massively overstated in relation to my field, which is not one in which essentially predatory journal publishers (Elsevier et al.) charge enormous fees for access to published scientific papers: the costs, in my area, outweigh the benefits

Q5: Phase 2: Early (e.g., Research Associate, first grant holder, Lecturer)
Q1.13: As far as I'm aware, our department/faculty does not provide specific training on co-producing, but it's something considered optimal and we're always encouraged to do this. As I work in the field of Applied Social Psychology, my team always focuses on building collaborative networks and disseminating knowledge as widely as possible.
Q2.12: As a primarily qualitative researcher, awareness of legal, ethical, and regulatory constraints is essential. All collection and use of data must be approved by the university's ethics committee, which is stringent in highlighting potential problems.
Q2.13: Due to the nature of qualitative research, legal, ethical, and regulatory constraints (e.g., maintaining participant anonymity) may outweigh other principles of open research (e.g., providing open and accessible data). So far, all qualitative publications I have co-authored have not made their datasets available for this reason. Even trying to remove all references to names, locations, etc., from interview/questionnaire data would not necessarily anonymise it, as descriptions of incidents and contexts could potentially allow participants to be identified.
Q3.13: I don't think my institution takes an all-encompassing approach to this topic or provides all-round training, as it comes down to individual departments to develop and communicate specific strategies for this. It has always been strongly encouraged by my line managers and PhD supervisors to make qualitative data practices (e.g., data collection and data analysis methods) transparent, e.g., by sharing and discussing all data coding within the team, outlining the methods fully and clearly in publications, etc.
Q4.12: Determining data acquisition, management, and storage, etc. before a study is very important, as is identifying existing evidence in the field on which to base the study (i.e., doing a literature review), but pre-determining specific ways of analysing qualitative data (e.g., "We'll definitely use grounded theory") can be problematic and limiting.
Q5.12: Using a pre-determined way of analysing qualitative data is problematic, e.g., the collected data may not fit the assumptions that a certain method of analysis will be optimal (e.g., it may not be detailed enough for IPA, but reflexive thematic analysis would offer new insights). Hypotheses are not used in qualitative research. Taking this approach would also undermine inductive data analysis.
Q5.13: Taking a one-fits-all approach would be problematic for qualitative research and potentially drive researchers away from it.
Q8.13: I think this is done very differently for quantitative and qualitative research (managing and recording changes to digital resources for the latter would mean things like removing 'ums' and 'ers' in transcripts, which we always discuss with the team and make clear in publications.
Q10.12: Making qualitative data re-usable is a controversial topic and is discussed by a number of papers.
Q16_11_TEXT: As explained earlier, some aspects of open research (e.g., providing reusable datasets) can be problematic or just not possible for qualitative research. The teams on which I work do as much to make our research open and transparent as is ethically and pragmatically possible.

Phase 2: Early (e.g., Research Associate, first grant holder, Lecturer)
Q2.12: Data required for modelling purposes can be subject to IP as can projects with particular partners. But beyond these cases, the main issue is one of training and support to use software and systems that enable transparent and open work. This is all left to the discretion of the researcher - there is no real and effective institutional objective here.
Q2.13: Make training and support in tools that enable open and transparent work a priority.
Q3.13: Qualitative work is not as clear a focus for my field of study but interacts with it.
Q6.12: Software currently used for my field of study are proprietary and all our existing IP, analysis, models, research ... relies on these software. Changing to open source options would be preferable but risks destroying the networks of influence that we have built within the UK over time.
Q6.13: Software used in my field of research are typically not open source. Being able to use corresponding software developed by others that ARE open source would be preferable.
Q7.13: There is no time to develop software for our work unless this is part of a well resourced project. There is no institutional support / money to support this otherwise.
Q8.12: The industry that we work in (energy modelling) is moving towards online version control system and open data sets for influencial models using e.g. Git Hub. We are currently failiing to follow this trend and make this change. We will eventually fall well behind the curve and loose influence and relevance as a result.
Q8.13: There is no funded time to work on increasing skills in this area. Generally speaking - there is no time on a typical working week to undertake any training unless using personal time or week ends.
Q9.12: Reproducibility of results is a condition of credibility. Without good version controls and storage systems it is not possible to achieve this. Our current approach to this is piecemeal at best and will eventually lead to issues. Being for example audited for project resutls would be a very painful experience as of today's date.
Q12.13: My institution has mandatory training on declaring conflicts of interest - but that is it. There is no follow up - and I do not know what additional suppor is available on this topic.
Q13.12: Pre-prints allow us to present results in a more timely way than waiting for a lengthy peer review process but is also an approach that is not always clearly endorsed by high end journals - e.g. Nature do not allow pre-prints. But these high end journals are part of our target journals and are very well regarded / encouraged when considering promotion.
Q14.12: OA is now a requirement for outputs from publically funded projects - but navigating this space is very complicated. Non compliance is not an option as it invalidates the inclusion of outputs in the REF which - again - is an expected contribution to the institution.
Q14.13: My institution library services provide what seems like good support for this process - but managing to streamline this even more and make it as easy as possible to comply for researchers would be beneficial - we are not experts in this and will eventually make a mistake that cannot be corrected.
Q16_11_TEXT: Many of the above. Selecting just one option is not possible as they are all interlinked.

Q1.13: 1.	Vouchering and specimen deposition for biodiversity research projects. From personal experience I can attest to the poor quality of insect identification in published papers. Which when one tries to check â specimens are unavailable / disposed of. Therefore you cannot validate results or repeat experiment because data are not verifiable. It should be made obligatory to deposit at the least a voucher collection (to museum standards)  of taxa in a publicly accessible collection.   2.	Deposition of raw data in a useable and publicly accessible format for biological recording (e.g. iRecord), conservation and further biodiversity research. For example, there have been several undergraduate, masters and DPhil projects utilising British dung beetles â yet not one of these has deposited their data with the Biological Records Centre or submitted to the National Recording Scheme. So when the conservation assessment for UK dung beetles was undertaken (see http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/publication/5488450394914816), data from Oxford research was unavailable. This will be true across various groups of animals and plants.

Q5.13: like much of these issues, it may have benefits when dealing with human subjects and ethically sensitive research.  But it would simply add to bureaucratic procedures in other areas to no good purpose, except to allow close monitoring of individual researchers work and be another step towards the proletarianisation of intellectual labour
Q11.12: I have to collaborate with researchers in other parts of the world to access materials and records.  They require/deserve recognition even where their intellectual contribution to a specific piece of work has been minimal.  Requirement to list the various contributions can be very problematic under such circumstances and would discourage collaboration in the future.
Q11.13: This requirement is related to the mindset which regards research as a commercial transaction (which of course it is in part).  However, it is the final publication (and associated datasets) whicbe seconh is important and should be seen as "the research".  The importance of individual author contributions should be secondary to this. It is making the system more competitive, cut-throat  and ruthless while masquerading under "fairness" (ie. the possibility of being fired easily for under-performance by your employer if you are going through a fallow period).  I am sufficiently senior that I know longer have to be over-concerned about where I stand in an author list.  It is a liberation and allows me to do more research.

Q1.12: It is a challenging to do this work because it involves working in teams with different needs and time scales. While you may be under tight deadlines from institutions and funders, those working with you from outside the institution to co-produce will not be. To balance involvement, versus meeting the demands of research and academia is tricky, but important.
Q2.12: Just the standard difficulty between balancing the importance placed by institutions and funders on open research, versus participants rights to privacy.
Q2.13: There is a disconnect between the importance of explaining research in an accessible way to participants, and the need to state a lot of complicated regulatory information in consent forms and information sheet. When I work to co-produce these documents, it is always the sections that university regulators require be included to approve studies that the co-production team (e.g. lived experience, patient representatives wish to be removed, edited, or put as supplementary information)

Q5: Phase 3: Mid/Recognised (e.g., Senior Lecturer, Reader, Senior Researcher)
Q1.12: A key challenge to co-production in many fields is that the relevant stakeholders are not prepared to get engaged and remain engaged over the life of the project. There are also a number of projects that don't benefit proportionately from the inputs required to develop strong co-production.
Q1.13: Researchers should be informed about and encouraged to think about co-production, but it should not be a requirement.
Q2.12: The challenges here relate more to the tasks related to fully open science rather than any legal or ethical issues.
Q2.13: Legal, ethical, and regulatory issues are usually (or should be) established before any science takes place. So compliance is different from open science.
Q4.12: This topic is fundamental to my work; risks or issues are only related to the things the data management plan aims to prevent, e.g. data loss, IT breaches.
Q4.13: Institutions and/or funders should have pre-completed data management forms to streamline the process.
Q5.12: Requirements for pre-registration can be ambiguous at times.
Q5.13: Pre-registration is good in spirit, but it also adds hassle to the work. If someone wants to get around the intentions behind pre-registration, they can do so fairly easily.
Q6.12: By using open source software, the pool of analysts is larger; this may allow people less qualified in aspects unrelated to the software to get in the mix.
Q7.12: The ability to share code is extremely important, but it can be an inefficient use of time to learn new coding just so it is for open source software.
Q8.12: I have found some people are less attentive to what it takes to maintain proper version control. Backups can be very important for double checking things.
Q8.13: I think each person needs to manage version control of those things for which they are personally responsible for managing overall.
Q9.12: Some data are secure, with restricted access, so most people won't be able to reproduce some of the work, realistically speaking - but it's possible.
Q9.13: Reproducing work is a really critical part of the scientific method, but it is less encouraged in many fields than in natural sciences, for example. Journals don't want to publish replication studies.
Q10.12: Similar to earlier responses; some data are secure so access is limited.
Q11.12: There are always worries that if you don't acknowledge/include someone (despite no substantive contribution from them), they will feel insulted or spiteful.
Q12.12: The guidelines around conflicts of interest can stop certain partnerships or funding opportunities, even though the science would be completely sound.
Q12.13: I have never understood why merely declaring conflicts of interest is treated like it makes a difference. If a conflict of interest is going to get someone to skew or falsify data, be bias in interpretation, etc., then declaring their conflict of interest won't change that, while in many cases, no third party would be able to confirm the bias, etc.

Q5: Phase 4: Established/Experienced (e.g., Professor, Principal Fellows or Scientists)
Q1.12: I can't remember what 'this topic' is referring to by this point in the survey. This is really poorly designed.
Q1.13: 'please feel free to evolve'? Is this a standard English expression? I do not know what this means.
Q2.9: everywhere. research councils, colleagues at other universities. This is a huge liability, and the way the national guidelines are written (at legal, council, and institution levels) is detrimental to the validity of our science and the safety of our research participants. It is shocking. I have now become involved in the national professional association for my discipline in order to try and offer better support and guidance. The way the UK interpreted GDPR is a joke, and the way quant data drives what people thing is 'science' means that qual sciences that work with living people are put in an impossible position between a legal rock and a policy/funder hard place.
Q2.12: The way REC is conducted, for example, is horrific. The legal/policy framework has no understanding of the century worth of ethical work social sciences have done to learn how to approach sensitive things like intellectual property, or untold numbers of types of personal private data, in responsible ways. But the way the UK interpreted GDPR ('gold plating' EU policy), and the overriding tendency for medical/pharma research to drive the Ethics and Open Science paradigms means we are being expected by our funders and universities to do illegal things that will put living individuals at risk. Or, we simply cannot do our work.
Q2.13: Please feel free to evolve... I like being human, thank you. no need.
Q3.12: Your definition links don't help. I know what 'qualitative data' is... but 'transparent' is not... well, transparent. What do you mean by transparant qualitative data? Do you mean that we include person identifiers so that another scientest to go interview our participants to see if we report it right? Do you mean we identify all of our possible biases (therefore all of our personal private data) upfront so that potential bias is declaired? Transparency is impossible. In fact it is detrimental. It puts people at risk. There have to be safeguards against transparency. It is good practice to show how un-transparent one is, methodologically, by indicating how you anonymise, etc. The academic industry is being run into the ground by people flouting nonsense terms without a grasp of the danger this presents to people who participate in our research.
Q3.13: This survey is very british. it has so many terms that don't quite mean anything, such that someone from outside the system â even though i've been here for over a decade â am left scratching my head trying to understand what these questions and key terms are asking.
Q4.12: Yes, people need to be trained in knowing what data looks like, but the thing is anything is potentially data. And you have to be able to bluff, in a project proposal and a grant application, and say you know what kind of data you are going to look for and etc. But the best research projects find so much more than they think they will, and often of an entirely different project/question. So the whole performance of proposals and hypothesis are a dance. What we need is a system that trains scholars to be ethical subjects in the midst of research, and then sets them free to study whatever happens to be in front of them.
Q4.13: REC and the way it interprets GDPR is a detriment to UK scholarship. If, in Brexit, the UK had gotten rid of GDPR, that would have be one clear positive for the whole mess. Instead, they took a docile bit of EU policy and fitted it with fangs and a cat of nine tails.
Q5.12: this would be murder for any early career scholar. Shocking that some disciplines do this.
Q5.13: your text boxes don't expand, which makes it hard to see what we say, and impossible to go through and proofread in any effective manner.
Q8.1: I am not aware of this
Q8.12: I think maybe you are talking about the legal implications of data crossing institutional borders and IP going back and forth between partner organisations... but I don't know. If this is what you are trying to say, then you should use simple language so that we can get what you are asking about. In my experience, legal departments are pretty inept, not cuz they don't know what they are doing, but because they are too important and see the big money disciplines (medicine, engineering) as their clients, and those of us in the social sciences who like chatting with people and working with small community groups aren't worth they time, cuz its chunk change compared to the big business implications on the otherside of the institution.
Q8.13: You should have a button that says 'i am not smart enough to understand the question, please let me skip'
Q9.13: I'm too stupid to understand this question, please let me skip.
Q10.9: disciplinary national professional bodies; UK Data Services
Q10.12: HUGE problems. FAIR is unethical, when you come down to it, as our data is either a legal/ethical land field or 'cleaned' to the point uselessness. funding bodies require the use of repositories, but the repository archivists (thankfully) have a better head than the funders.
Q10.13: qualitative field notes are so private, asking these to be made open access is ill informed. it will be the death of any real ethnographic science if it continues. or, we simply train the trick of the hand and upload useless files to satisfy the policy. but even here, if data includes life stories, or anything about a person, then it is not only liable under GDPR to be anonymised, but also carries the IP of the research subject. So to have this open access is stupd, as that is an act of theft against the research participant. to strip their name is also an act of theft, as it takes something that is human, particular (and thus data) and makes it anonymous. absolute shambles. UKRI should be ashamed of itself.
Q11.1: I am not aware of this
Q11.12: k, so your tick boxes above don't allow for the institution to take a punitive approach. co-authorship is still rare in my discipline (or, my part of the discipline), but i think it absolutely imperative that if a student helped in develop a paper, or whatever, they are listed as an author (unless it was just a footnote type idea, then you name an honour them in a footnote). But both internally and in big things like REF, it is unclear how to deal with coauthored works, as there is not a standard approach, and it is unclear if they 'count' at all, and some clear cases where they at least don't 'count' as much. but, often coathoring something is as much or more a labour of love and intellectual rigour than a sole authored piece.
Q11.13: you need to repeat the main topic at the top of the 2nd/3rd page so that forgetful people like me can go back and reread the point of the conversation.
Q12.12: everyone has a conflict of interest. our disciplinary writing on ethics and methods are full of ominous levels of nasal gazing. I wouldn't recommend most of this, but it is useful to at least have some of it. Apparently, because capitalism, we only declare conflicts of interest when money or employment (money) is on the line. Unless we work in government, then we simply leak another scandal and wait for it to blow over.
Q12.13: It's hard to tell how long this survey is going to take. I'm getting board, and feeling alienated because of how much I don't understand what is going on.
Q13.13: another for that 'skip this section, it's not relevant to my science'
Q14.12: OA is awful. I hate it so much. I've heard all the arguments, I've been invovled on all sides of the process â author, editor, etc. of books, articles, whole academic journals. I hate it so much. It needs to stop. Yes, we need to get rid of the rapacious publishing giants. We also need to get rid of this government. But shifting the cost of publishing from the reader to the author is not going to solve the problem.
Q14.13: We used to have everything Open Access. Anyone who wanted could go into the British Library, or any number of other libraries the world over, or order things by post. Knowledge was open. But, now, with Open Access also comes CC licensing, which means that not only is it free to read, but the author and the institution no longer own it in any real way. The work can be adapted, etc, unless specific CC stipulations are added.... stipulations specifically forbidden by UKRI.
Q16_11_TEXT: There is no consideration of the massive ethical and legal implications for the kind of data my science deals with. Open and Transparent policies make it harder, if not impossible, to conduct oneself in an ethical manner, in a manner that honours the trust given us by our research participants. Policies like this are driven by the giants of the comercialisation of scholarship, and destroy the working lives and sanity of other kinds of scientists who do not fit the big data or pharma models.

Q5: Phase 2: Early (e.g., Research Associate, first grant holder, Lecturer)
Q1.12: Most of the support offered is for empirically focused studies. As a non-empirical research (in philosophy of education) I do not usually benefit from such kinds of training.
Q1.13: Less of an exclusive focus/hierarchisation of empirical studies would be really helpful, not only to me as a researcher but also, I believe, to the actual topic/research approach more broadly. I see this in my own students - e.g. postgraduate students, who I supervise and who usually do empirical studies, some of which involves co-production and could greatly benefit from a more theoretical underpinning as to what they are doing and why.
Q2.12: Again, as a philosopher of education involved in non-empirical study, this is not something that I am overly concerned with.
Q2.13: As a philosopher of education, I AM concerned with broader questions around ethics and the ethical implications of study and research. But this isn't how ethical requirements tend to be treated in my institution - or more broadly in my experience. It seems to be something bolted on at the end rather than an implicit part of the entire process. I think philosophers are much more reflexive about this than those who only do empirical research and apply for research ethics (e.g. using a template that doesn't require deeper levels of reflection),
Q3.12: Again, not directly a concern for non-empirical researchers. Although it is often assumed to be - usually by those with little understanding of what philosophers actually do!
Q3.13: Again, not directly a concern for non-empirical researchers. Although it is often assumed to be - usually by those with little understanding of what philosophers actually do!
Q4.13: Unless you refer to basic data management, like computer software (Word documents etc.) then this isn't really relevant to me or to many of my colleagues.
Q6.12: Plagiarism and self-plagiarism is a barrier to my field. We rely on an open platform for sharing and discussing our ideas, for making connections across those ideas. I think it is important to recognise other people's works, but to take complete ownership of ideas as if you are the only person to think of them is really misguided.
Q6.13: Plagiarism and self-plagiarism is a barrier to my field. We rely on an open platform for sharing and discussing our ideas, for making connections across those ideas. I think it is important to recognise other people's works, but to take complete ownership of ideas as if you are the only person to think of them is really misguided.

Q5: Phase 2: Early (e.g., Research Associate, first grant holder, Lecturer)
Q1.12: Difficult to get involvement from professionals, mainly because they're overwhelmed with work due to a recruitment crisis in the sector. Involving members of the public can be difficult because they may not see immediate relevance of methodology questions, and clinicians often see my field of study as "mere admin" aka "Why would you waste time and money on that?".
Q1.13: We often experience problems when applying for funding: reviewers often come from a background that means they see our area of methodology as admin aka "not the sciencey bit", and think that answers "are obvious". This reflects a perception that science is coming up with the original question, and perhaps the analysis element, but how you collect the data is not "science". Therefore they're not interested in funding in the area, nor in funding any co-production work with those professionals who have to make "collecting the data work" and know that "it's not obvious".
Q2.12: I work in a very highly regulated area in which calls for open science are increasingly loud. Many of the open science methods are easy to implement (i.e. the sector has suggested clear pathways), but some areas are trickier, such as the fact that we work with sensitive data that is almost impossible to anonymise. Guidance can at times be confusing and intimidating. Also, with longer term projects funding may not have been obtained to aid with data sharing for example, and this can make data sharing after the project ends difficult
Q2.13: Funders often demand open science practices but fail to provide adequate funding.
Q3.7_8_TEXT: Too general: we often have specific needs that aren't catered for in one-size-fits-all training. Training is good quality and probably good for most, but I often know more than the trainer
Q3.9: UK Data Archive, HDR UK, ICO
Q3.12: None, other than insufficient funding to do it as we'd like to!
Q3.13: I don't think it's that my institution is passive, but i don't feel that they either ensure compliance or reward. We are encouraged to do things, but there's no real carrot or stick.
Q4.7_8_TEXT: It's a fundamental part of my field so within department help is very good. Having said that, it follows the regulatory requirements: where there isn't a regulatory need it's not as well followed through, and training is less tailored, and more general to the whole institution
Q5.13: For some areas of my work, pre-registration is mandatory, for others, not at all. Where there is an appropriate pre-registration option we seek to comply.
Q6.12: Open source software is not the most widely used software, many collaborators and colleagues expect the use of Stata.
Q6.13: It can be difficult to use open software as the institution does not give administrator privileges on computers to most staff. When software is permitted it often isn't updated frequently enough, and there can be restrictions e.g. packages in R may not be downloadable
Q7.9: Another institution did a day symposium
Q8.13: Extremely important in my field in general, so all staff are rigorously trained. Even in my allied work that means that everyone continues to conduct version control as it's second nature: it also makes life a lot easier!!
Q9.12: Funding needs to be higher to allow for the extra work in ensuring all coding and analysis is of a high quality across areas of our work where this is not a regulatory requirement: where funding is inadequate it can place a big strain on researchers as they are rewarded for publications and "a result" and there aren't rewards for doing things well
Q9.13: This is a regulatory requirement for much of the work in my department. That mentality therefore pervades our allied work.

Q1.12: Patients/non-stake holders aren't necessarily involved in non-clinical research
Q2.12: Storage of rawdata on cloud servers can be tricky to know if complies even if anonymised. Since some metadata is needed in research for covariate correction.
Q2.13: There is no reward for spending time on this process for the individual researcher, additional infrastructure where compliance could be checked by an expert rather than a training video then do it yourself would be helpful.
Q4.12: It is on the author of a paper to have their code documented to a good standard only when submitting to a journal. The code is not checked in detail and can be a checkbox exercise. It may not run or is not of sufficient detail to be reproduced.
Q4.13: Universities take a passive approach to this and it is left to the researcher to comply. Again it would be useful to incentivise researchers to have reproducible code.
Q5.12: I have heard about this approach but have never seen it in practice. Again this seems to come from journal submission and nothing to do with the university.
Q5.13: Universities should again incentivise this approach in collaboration with grant bodies and journals instead of taking a passive approach.
Q6.12: No reward or incentive other than journal submission or collaborations with other reseachers to do this.
Q6.13: It is an incredibly important approach but can require a large amount of time to get to a high/reproducible standard. At the moment there is no incentive to do this - new results are more important than making code accessible for others.
Q7.12: Time and effort. I would like to make sure approaches/code I have taken can be used by others. But again this involves adding to my current workload since new results are the main goal.
Q7.13: Awards of funds for having open source code would help to justify time spent on this.
Q8.13: I do version control for personal back up. There is no reason currently to make this public and usually is done in a private repository.
Q9.12: Time and Incentives. To work quickly and get results there is no incentive to go back and make code reproducible unless for journal submission or to help the field. This again takes time which is not appreciated.
Q10.12: Again no reason to do this other than journal submission.
Q10.13: Currently long term storage of files is useful to submit to public repositories when a project is finished so that data is accessible but also is then not incurring cloud storage charges. A university public storage repository that doesn't incur charges would motivate researchers and help.
Q11.12: This is done on a lab by lab basis and there to the best of my knowledge is no set standard.
Q11.13: Some definitions that don't involve subjective assessments of "contribution" would be helpful.
Q12.12: Haven't had any conflicts of interest yet so am not sure.
Q12.13: Even with a conflict of interest - once it is stated people still report and present relevant results. Not sure how this could be improved but doesn't seem great in practice.
Q13.13: It is a really useful way to get papers out rather than going through a lengthy review process and getting scooped. Also, helps to get relevant research sooner.
Q14.12: Open access is only one by the journal and many journals fight against this. The university does nothing.
Q14.13: We are now required to submit open access papers because of grant requirements, but again this has nothing to do with the university. Without that it probably would not happen because the most prestigious journals do not want open access and require huge fees. These fees aren't currently factored into grant costs. The universities need to take a tougher stance with publishers - especially the most prestigious ones who can make or break careers.
Q16_11_TEXT: Lack of funding but there should not be open access costs this is linked to journals still charging exorbitant prices/profiteering and this is not being tackled by government and universities - it is a waste of public and charity money.

Q2.13: Good research takes time. Open research (e.g. creating and publishing reproducible code) takes more time. For me the main barrier to do more in this respect is general workload. Teaching and administrative loads for academics at my university have become unreasonably high, while research demands have not diminished. This stifles people's ability to engage in innovative open research practices.
Q6.13: The problem is that it is hard to get funding for training in software for academics. As soon as I was a lecturer, it seems the assumption is that I can train myself in new open-source software. There were no funds for me to attend trainings. Free training at UCL was on much too basic a level for my needs.
Q14.12: The main problem with (gold) open access publishing is lack of funds being made available to do so. Not all papers come from grants that have open access journal fees factored in. UCL used to financially support some open access publishing. As far as I'm aware, this budget is completely gone.

Q5: Phase 1: Junior (e.g., PhD candidate, Research Assistant)
Q1.13: Didn't fit into PhD process. Would have liked to include it but my research is so poorly supported from an academic point of view that I had to prioritise. Mainly due to poor supervision, i.e., supervisor does not understand my topic.
Q2.7_8_TEXT: More about damage control than actually cultivating a culture of ethical practise.
Q2.12: As it stands, ethics (as it's called) is mainly a bureaucratic hurdle people dread; rather than a constructive process for higher quality research.
Q2.13: Like all other things at UCL, there are no quality control checks for the values and experiences felt in each department. As a result, in my department at least, messages from UCL are felt distant and secondary. All we see about research ethics are endless webpages and forms, corporate style training videos, and opaque decisions from ethics committees. There are no active attempts to engage with the research community on the benefits of ethical research practises.
Q5.1: I am not aware of this
Q6.12: Open source software is often not in the pre-approved list of software packages available for download on UCL computers.
Q6.13: Open source software should be encouraged whenever possible; that is, when there's a viable open source alternative to any given task. This will ensure higher research reproducibility.
Q7.12: My research data is not publicly available. Therefore, the code is not directly applicable and may have hard to spot aspects I am not allowed to share.
Q7.13: Although my research wouldn't have been possible without proprietary data, I don't think a University should support this type of opaque research practises. Computational research is only reproducible if all aspects of it are public (i.e., data, code/procedure, analysis), not just the analysis. Training on how to best share these novel elements should not be optional or as minimal as it is. The passive approach of sporadic voluntary workshops with very limited capacity does not reflect the central role these practises should have. Please, with this and other essential research training activities, pressure our institutions into hosting world-leading training activities fitting of their global status.
Q8.9: Other research institutions and in general online resources
Q8.12: Any training or learning process (e.g., learning git) is seen as questionable use of time that could be spent delivering results and publications.
Q8.13: It could certainly be a great time saver (in the long run), and increases research quality. But for someone without a computer science background, version control software usage takes time getting used to. This time is seen as a waste especially when your supervisors are also not from CS background. As with other things, the pressure to publish and produce during a PhD trumps good research practises.
Q9.12: Same thing as version control. I see it's value and would like to achieve it, but the incentives are to cut corners. If anything, if I told my supervisor I need an extra week to make sure my code is reproducible she would think it very wasteful.
Q9.13: It's also not as relevant to ensure computational reproducibility when my data is not even public.
Q10.1: I am not aware of this
Q10.12: Can't do it, my data is not public.
Q10.13: Yet another reason why Universities shouldn't support research like mine, with proprietary data.
Q11.12: I can't be truthful about author contributions when it's my supervisors that are taking advantage of the power imbalance in our relationship.
Q11.13: I think it's the greatest sign of the corruption of our scientific process when we all just accept that seniority means you get your name of scientific publications you gave no intellectual contribution to. My supervisor, and most senior researchers in my department, use PhD student (and junior researchers) as free sources of publications. We have all come to accept that, no matter how distant or unqualified, a supervisor gets to put their name on publications from their students. UCL is far from being an exception and it applies no visible measures to prevent this happening.
Q12.13: I find the online training here to be suffient.
Q13.1: I am not aware of this
Q13.12: I'm too new to the publishing process to have an opinion.
Q14.13: The heavy push to Open Access is, in my opinion, one of the few major victories at UCL and UK institutions.

Phase 2: Early (e.g., Research Associate, first grant holder, Lecturer)
Q1.13: I think it is very important for the research field's impact & reach, but that it is not "necessary" for research so isn't always included. There is certainly no training or practical worked examples for junior researchers to use. It is all quite adhoc and depends who you work with.
Q2.12: GDPR etc. violations are risky for the field as we deal with huge amounts of personal data in large surveys. Also going too far with data protection is risky for the field as we need to use data from survey respondents so not having access to it is an issue too.
Q2.13: There is a lot of training on GDPR but I think the training does feel like a tick-box exercise for compliance but means that understanding is sometimes not that great, especially when applying the principles to a situation that is not covered in the training (which happens a lot as the training is very general) or even just more everyday activities where GDPR actually still applies
Q3.12: Transparency is important for the field with regards to all research methods
Q3.13: I don't use qual but I think it is an important part of social sciences and large surveys and having transparency in all types of research method is important
Q4.12: Barriers with this topic in my field come more from the sharing of code as the data sources are generally well documented and managed professionally. Barriers come from the lack of shared code that was used for an analysis so replication is tricky even with the same data.
Q4.13: Data management plans are very important for the field but less for individual researchers as we often don't collect data ourselves but use secondary data that professionals manage and plan. Transparency around the origin, sharing etc. of this data is very important but done at a study level
Q5.12: Barriers are that many people in my field don't do pre-reg reports and I find there aren't many examples or training exmples of pre-reg reports for secondary data analysis of big surveys. I think a barrier/risk that people think in this field is that publishing what you will do before you do it will mean someone else will do it first, which is obviously easier when the data already exists than when you are collecting it
Q5.13: I think they are important for all research fields but i think they require a huge culture change in academia, as people are still touchy about people "stealing ideas" etc.
Q6.6: At too complex a level,At too basic a level
Q6.12: Barrier to open access software is mainly knowledge of how to use it. Historically people have used paid for software, so quite a shift for the whole field to move to a different software e.g. Stata to R
Q6.13: I think it is important as it opens up the field to more people, but i think there needs to be specialist training in how to use the software for the field specifically - I've found training to either leave you with a basic knowledge and no idea how to scale that to your research/data or too complex - needs a middle ground
Q7.12: Barriers to making you own software are knowledge and time
Q7.13: Making your own software is less important in my field, but making it open access if you do I think is important.
Q8.12: Barrier is knowledge of systems to do this & not having good examples/precedence - all very adhoc
Q8.13: Version control is important but there is not clear emphasis on this for researchers in my field. we are not trained in it so up to who you work with or your own motivation as to whether and how you do it.
Q9.12: Barrier is there's little incentive to share code etc. that makes reproducibility possible
Q9.13: Reproducibility should be so easy in my field as the data is often available to researchers, but code is hardly ever shared and all data prep steps are glossed over so it is still difficult. I also think it is quite daunting to share code online sometimes, like you are opening yourself up to judgement and criticism if something is slightly wrong or inefficient in your code; but this stifles the sharing

Q14.12: Open access fees for journal publications can be very high. While it is possible for people with research funding to get these fees paid for under a block grant or similar, colleagues not in that fortunate position are not able to. Requirements to publish open access (rather than just upload a pre-print/accepted manuscript/similar to an open access repository) for inclusion in REF and similar exercises is therefore creating a two-tier system of people who can and those who can't afford to do this and is deeply unhelpful.
Q14.13: This area needs to evolve to consider researchers (including doctoral students) not able to afford exorbitant open access fees.

Q9.13: institutions seem to not care about computational reproducibility

Q13.12: no training needed; people should just do it
Q13.13: no training needed; people should just do it

Q1.9: Come across on social media; perhaps not actively looked but have been intrigued by
Q1.13: I'm in the field of anthropology where there is a strong colonial/imperialist history. I believe that many researchers are aware of this and try to remedy that in their work through co-production but sometimes find it hard to assess or understood if it is done with sincerity and with an attention to ethics or if it is lip service. Generally I think there's a lot of awareness and training opportunities at UCL.
Q2.13: Filling in ethics forms is one thing but pursuing genuine reflexiveness is another--I wish we had more opportunities as a cohort to reflect on our methods while undertaking fieldwork.
Q3.12: Transparent qualitative data sharing is very hard, in my opinion, without compromising the anonymity of my respondents' data. Interviews are very context-rich and to redact all identifying information would make them quite thin as well as possibly change the meanings of the responses.
Q3.13: I think however there is value in working in labs rather than in silos. Being able to cross-check coding or discuss field observations is invaluable in creating transparency.
Q4.13: We do have training in terms of GDPR regulations that we must undertake and a lot of stuff about where to store data. However in practice I imagine it's very hard to keep up (e.g. uploading all transcripts to a protected server when Internet access is poor) -- also it can be very tedious.

Q13.13: I am uncertain what the value of pre-prints is and whether or not my dept supports training in this matter.
Q14.13: I find open access can be quite expensive and I don't have to funds to pay for it. I do think my discipline has a great deal of blogs and open-access journals that one can submit to. Q14.12: The requirement of publishing open access is a good idea in principle, but I feel this has led to many new journals being created, the quality and rigour of which is not always entirely underpinned by the quality of research but instead by money. Q5: Phase 1: Junior (e.g., PhD candidate, Research Assistant)
Q1.12: Analysis of high energy physics data typically requires good understanding of maths, programming and physics. Datasets are very large so must be hosted of large computing clusters, hard to see how such resources could be accessible to the general public. As for running of detector and construction of components, this requires specialist knowledge
Q1.13: Hard to see how this idea of 'coproduction' applies to a highly technical field such as HEP. Initiatives such as ATLAS open data are highly important for outreach, but its hard to see how collaboration with non physicists/engineers would be helpful when performing analysis of LHC data
Q2.13: Not sure how GDPR is relevant to HEP outside of general collaboration organisation. For day-to-day research this is irrelevant
Q3.1: I am not aware of this
Q3.12: Irrelevant - HEP is not a qualitative research field
Q4.12: LHC data is very expensive so must be preserved. Likewise code is very important to keep backed up and version controlled on github
Q4.13: Try to keep code backed up and version controlled on github where possible. Data is less of a concern since this is handled centrally either by ATLAS/CERN or locally at institutions
Q5.13: In ATLAS before a new analysis is started there is a kick-off meeting in the relevant sub-group where the feasibility and  motivation of the analysis is presented to other colleague, who are then invited to collaborate if this analysis is appealing to them. Once an analysis is started a database entry is made in Glance which keeps track of contributors, internal documentation, progress and targeted timeline. Guess this is kinda what similar to this Preregistration plan thing??
Q6.13: HEP data analysis benefits greatly from open source software, particularly when it comes to python and C++ packages
Q7.12: Analysis code is typically kept private and is hosted on CERN servers - only other collaboration members have access
Q7.13: Whilst the exact analysis code is typically kept private, a lot of the software that is used is open source - see ROOT, uproot, Madgraph, pythia ect...
Q8.12: Only in that our datasets are extremely large, finding computing resources is a challenge. This motivates a transition to lighter-weight formats like DAOD-PHYS-LITE
Q8.13: Version control is a core part of our research
Q9.12: While in principle it should be possible to reproduce any ATLAS research (with enough effort) in practice it can be very challenging. Particularly when it comes to replicating simulated datasets and setting up computing environments. Code is not always well documented and the original authors may of left ATLAS/physics.
Q9.13: There are a lot of technical barriers in HEP to making analysis reproducible, but there are some growing initiatives such as rivet and RECAST to improve this
Q10.12: While all data is in principle findable and accessible - the tools for this are less than ideal. Small datasets that we actually use in analysis that are derived from large ones are harder to find/access since these are typically stored on local clusters and get deleted if they go unused and space is required (They could be reproduced in principle, but in practice this could be hard)
Q10.13: Datasets in HEP are not always in easy to to read formats - while they can be converted - this requires expertise and special software. The move in ATLAS to move away from AOD to DAODPHYS-LITE ought to help
Q11.12: The war in Ukraine has meant that ATLAS has stopped publishing papers while the issue of what to do with Russian institutions is resolved
Q11.13: Publicly it can be difficult to tell which people directly had a hand in an publication, anyone who contributes to the running of ATLAS becomes an author on all papers. The recognition of those directly involved in the analysis is tracked and documented internally
Q13.13: All papers published by CERN experiments are preprinted on ArXiv
Q14.13: All research published by CERN experiments is open access
Q16: Lack of supporting infrastructure (e.g., sufficient storage for open data / publishing platform for open monographs)

Q1.12: lack of skills perhaps or tight timescales - might not be possible to get stakeholder insight into research when a 2 year project and 3 WPs
Q1.13: Co-production is great. NIHR and other grant funders look for it.

Q4.12: ethical concerns of sharing data collected about people's health status
Q4.13: I am crap at data management. Should learn best practices from ecology and other env sciences who do this better than me in psychology
Q5.12: lack of knowledge of where to pre-reg a study

Q8.12: risks of not doing this are great
Q8.13: I am crap at data management. It is embarrassing. Would love the best practice for version control in data. But am too embarrassed to ask for help (I do a reasonable job of version control for text)

Q11.9: online at Nature or Science guidelines for author recognition
Q11.12: Not doing it at the start of a manuscript development. It usually comes up towards submission or based on journal's guidance for contribution. Disagreements can arise at this point
Q11.13: As a woman I have had to rely on a journal's authorship guidelines to argue for senior authorship. Guidelines that are not linked to a specific journal, but are general, would be preferable
Q12.9: At my old job in Germany we had training on conflicts of interest - what gifts we can/cannot accept

Q14.12: Lack of funding - if there is no funding for open access APC then one cannot publish open access or in such journals.
