Q5: Phase 3: Mid/Recognised (e.g., Senior Lecturer, Reader, Senior Researcher)
Q1.13: It wasn't clear whether "co production" included commercial end-user involvement in research; if so, then this is almost a prerequisite in our discipline (we need to be able to show commercial return-on-investment for research funding).
Q2.12: There are concerns about disclosing techniques, code etc. that took enormous personal investment to develop- these can then be easily used by others, reducing your professional advantage.
Q2.13: I wonder how important this would be if we didn't have performance management targets... there was a time before these perverse personal incentives when scientists could just be trusted.
Q4.13: Data management plans are statements explaining that we will use best practices in science. It isn't clear why this is more important or singled out from any experimental methodology: why don't we then need "instrument calibration plans", "model validation plans" or "data post-processing plans"?
Q5.12: (not relevant to my field of study)
Q5.13: (not relevant to my field of study)
Q6.12: (none - it's highly enabling, not a barrier)
Q6.13: It is quite common in my field for open-source models and software to be used, although I rarely use these myself.
Q7.12: The only risk is that others will use your work to their own benefit, and you won't receive the reward/recognition.
Q7.13: Sharing things you've developed for the benefit of others, although altruistic, isn't consistent with the current system of rewards in HEIs. My rewards are based exclusively on grant revenue and REFable outputs; these in turn must be unique and novel- so there is a strong disincentive to share my tools.
Q8.13: Although others in my field do this, it is not relevant to my own work.
Q9.13: In my area, this is done as a matter of course; results which can not be computationally reproduced using declared methods are, by definition, falsified. Some variability in precision/accuracy is accepted, either because of specific implementations (trivial) or computational limitations (a constraint), but these must fall within the decared uncertainty.
Q10.12: The volume of data produced by our work is itself prohibitive: I have no problem sharing it, but you'd need to ship me a pallet-load of hard drives for me to actually give it to you. Most users aren't interested in the data, but in the post-processed results which are easily summarised and can be harvested directly from published work.
Q11.12: Again, we are rewarded for publications and grant revenues, so there is a strong incentive to 'game' authorships and co-investigatorships to maximum advantage.
Q11.13: It would be really nice if 'authorship' actually meant 'who worked on and wrote this output'- but it's now largely interpreted as 'who should benefit from the metrics generated by this output'. Senior acadmics producing a paper a week cannot possibly be contributing in any substantial way to them. There is no control of this currently in our discipline area- and it is probably needed: "secured the funding for this project" is not a scientific contribution.
Q12.13: This is treated as a legal/liability issue by the institution, and is therefore taken very seriously.
Q13.1: I am not aware of this
Q13.13: (not relevant to my field of study)
Q14.12: The pay-to-publish model is a very dangerous one, again because of the performance-management targets we now have. Open access in a good thing, but great care must be taken in training new academics about the possible danger of having their fears about targets exploited.
Q14.13: I currently publish all my papers, 'as accepted' but unformatted, as open access via the university's repository at no cost. I do not engage with pay-to-publish journals.

Q1.12: In condensed matter physics we are usually dealing with difficult objects, data and experiments. But in the case of condensed matter physics, this level will turn non-specialist to specialist.
Q1.13: Sharing ideas and points of views is always useful and pleasant. Usually, once we found something really great in physics, it turns into an engineering matter. There might be some scope for crowd-sourcing aspects like (manual) image analysis but computational methods are increasingly making this unnecessary.
Q2.7_8_TEXT: Very uneven. I conduct workshops promoting open science practices for one large PhD programme, but I'm not aware of an institute-wide programme for PhD or other levels.
Q2.12: No significant field-specific barriers to open science
Q2.13: My institution has initiatives in this area and is working towards this as part of Research Integrity but comprehensive actiion has not yet been taken.
Q3.7_8_TEXT: See my answers to the previous (Open Science) question. Issues of uneven application are the same.
Q3.13: See my previous answers - to recap, the will is there, some training is available but is very unevenly available.
Q4.13: Data Management Plans are mandatory for UKRI BBSRC/MRC grants and therefore completely routine in my field.
Q5.12: My field is highly exploratory discovery science and changing the research question is not only unavoidable but is often desirable.
Q5.13: I think pre-registration is great where practicable, but does not lend itself to application in exploratory research.
Q9.13: Surely this is an integral aspect of Open Science (referred to earlier in the survey)?
Q11.13: This is a poorly phrased survey question in the sense that it is unclear whether the answers should be normoative ("should be important") or descriptive ("are actually important"). In fact the issues around giving credit are not all that explicit in my field but inherently difficult to define and require much more detailed consideration than is possible in this type of survey.
Q12.9: UC San Francisco (where I am a co-investigator) which has extensive on-line training, monitoring/compliance mechanisms
Q12.13: My institution's approach is rather patchy.
Q13.13: The utility of pre-prints is over-rated. They are useful for career development (to show productivity before final publication) but do not really accelerate research - just muddy the publication and peer-review process.
Q14.13: "Training" is actually non-existent because none is really necessary (it is only a question of choosing the right open access licence according to the requirements of the funder and accessing the relevant OA funding (UKRI block grant).

Q3.12: I do not work in a field that generates large external datasets through (e.g.) surveys, interviews, or polling. Instead, open data is much more about the transparent citation and description of the sources used for historical inquiry. The exception is the study of new and previously unpublished artefacts. For these, there are important ethical standards that have been developed by scholars and professional organizations. The University fails to make these standards part of its own research guidelines and some members of the University (in my field and adjacent fields) do not uphold these professional best practices.

Q1.1: I am not aware of this
Q1.12: I do not believe so, as a computational chemist I am removed from other stakeholders. I feel like if non-researchers were to become more involved it would be at a different level. For example if I aid in the synthesis of a new Drug I feel like stakeholders would be involved at the trial and treatment level rather than at my level.
Q1.13: Although it is not relevant to me, I feel this is hugely important particularly for medical studies. Often the intersection of patients, families and doctors is where the most impactful research occurs. I think providing training in these fields would be incredibly valuable especially when a lot can go wrong particularly when involving patients.   I also feel like placing an emphasis on respecting patients is very important, I have heard stories where patients feel used or ignored when researchers involve them but do not include them (even if just explaining which stage the research is at) in the process.
Q2.12: I do no research that involves the personal data of individuals.
Q2.13: I believe it is important and I know the University has policies related to this however it is not relevant to my field.
Q3.12: This is not really relevant to my research. I may produce images and graphs
Q4.12: Releasing data or losing it is something that is often considered, particularly as most of my data is digital. There is a risk of data being stolen or lost.
Q4.13: Defining what data you will use and how it will be stored beforehand is very helpful. I often find you need to think about it less when there are schemes provided to you, for example free one drive or storage available in your shared computer facility.
Q5.1: I am not aware of this
Q5.12: I am not aware of doing something like this for computational chemsitry.
Q5.13: I think it is something I could see being more important to other fields.
Q6.9: Blogs and videos, Github has good articles
Q6.12: Open source software is hugely important to computational research. It is very rare that I do not need to change the source code of a program, make adjustments or adapt what someone else has done to my work. Badly shared code often wastes a lot of my time, and if I do not have access to software source code it can limit me in my resaerch.
Q6.13: I feel like this is widely relevant to many fields, not just computational fields either. Writing good code that is well documented means that with very little training an experimental group can pick up what you have done and use it in a project.
Q7.12: Writing your own open source code improves you research as well as you can have other people test and improve it.
Q8.12: Version control is very important, our group develops software and this software has often been through the hands of multiple generations of PhD student. Having good version control enables us to continue work rather than starting from scratch.
Q8.13: Version control is not only important for code but also for writing papers/reports. Tracking changes and keeping track of versions of a paper can improve the write up process but I feel like it is emphasized less.
Q9.12: This is a massive barrier - if your work is difficult to reproduce then less people will care about your work and having to use other peoples work that is difficult to reproduce wastes a lot of time on my end.
Q9.13: Although it is very important, I don't know how you would come up with general training as I feel each field has different needs. I do think an emphasis of good coding practices and documentation could be a good step, as then at the very lest your code is understandable and more likely to be reproducible.
Q10.12: I think every researcher should want their research to be FAIR.
Q10.13: The issue is not a lack of emphasis within research. If research falls short of this it is often because a researcher lacks a core skill, be it writing clearly or breaking down ideas well so people outside your group can understand. This is often emphasised at institutions at undergraduate level, I feel like there could be more emphasis for postgraduates.

Q13.12: I am not aware of this.
Q14.12: I feel like most research should be open access, but I don't see how training researches addresses this.

Q2.13: I see the value of having a compliance/monitoring approach here as there are severe consequences to not getting things right. However I think my institution also does really well to try to emphasise that this isn't just about box-ticking. Unfortunately I'm not sure this is always fully received or processed by all colleagues, some of whom seem to think things like ethics are about box-ticking and that effort to unpack complexities here is questioning of their authority and mistrustful, rather than approaching this as a constructive and complex process. This is not to say this is the case for all, but there's certainly some underlying narratives in some corners to this effect.

Q3.12: There can be reservations about things like open sharing qualitative data because of worries around epistemology and positioning as well as the identifiability of participants. There are some instances where I have opted not to make data public, for instance, because of the nature of conversations and potential risk to participants, as well as concerns that they would be less comfortable sharing on sensitive topics if they knew full accounts would be made available.
Q3.13: There is a big push toward open science in our institute as a whole at the moment; some local colleagues feel that the language and general principles are not aligned to qualitative work. As a mixed methods researcher I don't really agree with them, but their reservation here is interesting and shows a perceived barrier for some in qualitative work particularly

Q12.12: A major reputational issue if the outcomes of the research result in IP that is of commecial value

Q3.12: Sharing qualitative data poses risk to participants of identification.
Q3.13: It is possible to be open about research practices, methods, etc for instance sharing topic guides and breakdown of analytic steps on qualitative analysis without putting participant identification at risk. Replication is not an issue in qualitative research, it is not something that we strive to do nor is it congruent with qual methodologies. However, sharing more detailed methods is very helpful so that the reader can understand how findings were developed and how the study was conducted.

Q1.12: the nature of research in number theory and pure maths more generally is that many years of training are needed to get to grips with the abstract concepts before research can be undertaken

Q3.13: pure maths research does not involve personal data
Q4.13: pure maths research does not involve personal data
Q5.13: pure maths research does not involve conducting studies
Q6.12: memory limits on free versions of the software can be a barrier and the cost of the full version is high
Q6.13: I don't use software much but many people in my field do, including my collaborators and my PhD students. It's very important to the field, even if not to my work in particular.
Q7.12: I don't think enough credit is given to creating software in academia, as compared to publishing papers
Q7.13: I don't create software personally but others do and it's very important to the field.
Q9.1: I am not aware of this
Q9.13: Pure mathematics research generally doesn't involve data analysis
Q10.12: If we have to pay to publish or are restricted as to which journals we can publish in, this is very bad, especially for early career researchers and people from less wealthy institutions
Q10.13: mathematicians have a strong tradition of putting their preprints on the arXiv, making them freely accessible to all
Q11.12: I think that attempts to quantify contributions will cause more problems than they solve and the subjectivity and power dynamics involved will be bad for EDI
Q11.13: in pure maths articles, the authors are listed in alphabetical order, which I think is very good and saves us from a lot of stress and politics. We do also include some non-authors in the acknowledgements section (for useful conversations etc) so there is a bar that has to be met to be considered an author. I think our system of shared authorship works very well.
Q12.13: conflicts of interest must be declared when doing research-related activities like applying for or giving out funding, for example. Not much training is needed - you just need to see the definition and examples of conflicts.
Q13.13: we have a strong tradition of putting all preprints on the online arXiv. It is self-explanatory, no training is needed.
Q14.12: being restricted in a choice of journals or punished for publishing in the wrong ones is very harmful to the careers of early career researchers and people at less wealthy institutions
Q14.13: Since we put all our work on the online arXiv, where it is freely available to all, I see no advantage in being restricted in our choice of journals and only the disadvantages mentioned above. For example, I heard someone saying that they'd discovered that Cambridge had an agreement with a prestigious journal, allowing Cambridge authors to publish there for free. So they planned to get a Cambridge coauthor for all their future papers. This was a joke (I think!) but you can see how these kinds of dynamics can skew the field even more in favour of the richest institutions.
Q16_11_TEXT: By "open research practices", I mean putting all preprints on the arXiv, which I and the maths community strongly support. If you mean publishing in Open Access journals, then this is something I do not support, for reasons already discussed.

Q5: Phase 1: Junior (e.g., PhD candidate, Research Assistant)
Phase 3: Mid/Recognised (e.g., Senior Lecturer, Reader, Senior Researcher)
Phase 3: Mid/Recognised (e.g., Senior Lecturer, Reader, Senior Researcher)
Q2.12: There are many risks involved in open science: it involves opening oneself to potential criticism by laying bare all the possible problems in one's work. That's as it should be, but it can become more problematic when people without relevant expertise may get hold of the data and misinterpret it. There's also the problem that as soon as one has released one's data, other researchers may 'scoop' one by publishing papers based on the same data.
Q2.13: I believe very passionately in open science, especially in releasing data and code. But while open science is valued by some of my peers, it is simply not recognised or rewarded on any institutional level -- whether by universities, by journals, by relevant professional associations. This means that one doesn't get anything at all in return for the risks taken.
Q3.12: Doing research like this gives critics many additional directions of attack, especially if they are unwilling to do the same in their own research practice. It's very exposing, in other words.
Q3.13: There are simply no rewards for following open principles in one's research practice. I wonder whether some people actually feel threatened by such principles, not wanting to adopt them in their own research. Whether or not that's the case, the fact is that there's no reward for taking the risks involved. It doesn't make editors or peer reviewers any more likely to accept one's papers. It doesn't make any difference to an application for promotion. Nobody cares, really.
Q4.12: Collecting data involves a vast amount of effort. Giving it away to people who haven't put that effort in doesn't always feel like a smart career move.
Q4.13: There's no way at all for this to be recognised within the framework of the REF, and for that reason it isn't rewarded by universities.
Q5.12: Unfortunately, many peer reviewers and editors still see failure to find a statistically significant result as failure. This means that not being able to rewrite your hypotheses or re-jig your analytic method following data collection is a disadvantage. For that reason, pre-registration feels like a huge risk. Don't get me wrong: I pre-register everything scrupulously. It's just that I know that this puts me at a disadvantage relative to those who don't share my scruples.
Q5.13: I have yet to come across an editor or peer-reviewer who commended my co-authors and me for pre-registering our hypotheses and methods. I don't think that most social scientists understand or care about the reasons for doing it. It's a scandal, really.
Q6.12: It can be harder to get published if you chose not to use particular bits of proprietary software. But it's always possible to get around that sort of problem.
Q6.13: Use of open source software is FAR LESS important than openness in data and analysis. However, researchers in my field treat it as if it was more important. It's almost a religion. I use open source software wherever possible, but honestly people make too much of a fuss about it relative to how much of an impact it actually has on research.
Q7.12: The biggest risk in releasing a piece of software for others to use is that those others will then expect the person who released it to answer their questions, fix problems, and generally provide free customer service. This is extremely time consuming. I don't have that time, really.
Q7.13: There are no real rewards for doing this, but people do seem to respect it on an informal level.
Q8.12: Version control feels very exposing because it leaves a visible trail of mis-steps and mistakes.
Q8.13: There is virtually no understanding of why version control matters, whether in my field or on the part of my employing university. The great majority of researchers don't even really know what it is.
Q9.12: Reproducibility is inherently a risk: if others can't reproduce a finding, there are few places to hide. There shouldn't be any shame in that, but unfortunately, there is.
Q9.13: The biggest problem here is actually that people don't even try to reproduce findings. I suspect that the reason for that is that big journals see replication studies as not being original, and therefore not being worthy of publication. This is wrong.
Q10.13: I didn't know what FAIR principles were. Thanks for alerting me to them!
Q11.13: Researchers in my field are pretty good on this
Q12.13: I think most researchers understand this intuitively and are quite good about it

Q5: Phase 2: Early (e.g., Research Associate, first grant holder, Lecturer)
Q1.12: Co-production per se doesn't present a huge risk or barrier, but the principle of restricting what researchers are allowed to work on is dodgy in my opinion and antithetical to science. Far better to motivate researchers to, e.g., work on topics that are relevant to autistic people, than to constrain what we're allowed to do.
Q1.13: Co-production is important to my field (developmental disorder, e.g. autism) but IMO better handled between grant funders and research teams, or individual labs. Institutional policies or requirements simply encourage paying lip service to whatever hoops researchers have to jump through. IMO to improve co-production we have to alter the prevailing culture within research groups. I'll tick any box you ask me to if it gets me a grant, but it doesn't mean I'll make any meaningful change. The biggest factor in changing my thinking on this was conversations with autistic people, and learning how well research does or doesn't affect them/improve their lives.
Q2.12: (1) For more junior members of large teams, and only if data are not embargoed to allow them a first bite, (2) there's a danger if you release all data openly that any random yahoo on the internet can misuse it. Many participants (particularly parents and carers who consent on behalf of study participants) are often unimpressed at the suggestion that their personal, medical data will be shared openly (3) friction with (often instutionally-led) desire to patent/spin off companies from findings. IMO this shouldn't be allowed, by the way -- if it's publicly funded it should be free to the public to use.
Q2.13: This is probably the most important thing to improving my field. Currently it is disincentivised. Career progression is so heavily based on papers (and grants, which are indirectly driven by papers) that researchers are almost solely incentivised for quantity over quality, and quality extends to research practices. If I were in charge I'd find ways to both incentivise and require open data and code sharing. There are downsides (see previous resposne) but overall I think better science is a higher goal and we should all just be forced to share everything. I don't do this because it's time away from more interesting/career-rewarding things, which is why I say I should be forced to do it.
Q3.12: Don't know enough about it to say
Q3.13: My only experience with qualitative methods was a course on my MSc which put me off for life. I'm probably too negative on the whole idea to have a reasoned opinion.
Q4.12: It doesn't present barriers, but barriers to adoption are the low technical skill level in psychology and human neuroscience. We need to train and pay people to do this sort of thing, independent from grants. This small investment will pay back massively in incresaed quality of science and better reproducibility.
Q4.13: It's vital, but most people don't realise. I know of a paper that was retracted because they made an error in their analysis code and flipped sex for each participant -- and it was a paper about "male/female" brains. Data gets lost, stored badly (wasting everyone's time), even the best people's code is usually poorly organised. Research software engineering needs a much higher profile.
Q5.12: This is partly sarcastic, but mandating preregistration would kill 90% of papers so there's a barrier there. I suspect people aren't as ignorant as they pretend on this topic, but instead they realise on some level that the gravy train would stop right quick if everyone was held to these standards.
Q5.13: It should be mandatory in almost all circumstances. We're (mostly) using public money to do this research, as well as getting paid with it, we should be made ensure it's as robust and reproducible (which is another way of saying "valuable to society") as possible. As with data/code sharing, I dont personally do it much because I'm disincentivised to in career-terms. Just making sure I do my analyses to my own personal standards puts me at a disadvantage from someone who doesn't care and never checks things.
Q6.12: In a perfect world, everyone would use FOSS for everything. In reality, we have to balance ideals with research productivity. FOSS documentation is often not great compared to commercial (e.g. matlab vs python/numpy) and I want to use the best tool for the job. However, in most cases FOSS is the best tool, or at least has the potential to be.
Q6.13: Ideally code sharing would in itself build a library of FOSS to be used by others. In reality you need research software engineer to be involved. I'd like to see researchers supported in making their code clean and usable in order to contribute to a useful library of FOSS.
Q7.12: Mostly that 90% of the code would be poor quality and undocumented. Need to upskill researchers and provide institutional support to make it workable.
Q7.13: It should be standard, but most people's code is not very useful. Research software engineers would help, especially if they were involved not only in research but also in training students in the basics.
Q8.13: This goes hand-in-hand with the question on DAPs and infrastructure. Versioning is a very obvious feature of an infrastructure for code and data that keeps everything properly organised. Again, though, we need the skills to make it happen.
Q9.13: I believe this should be the bare minimum expected of a researcher.

Q2.13: It is badly done and generally unnecessary.
Q4.12: It risks being turned into box ticking exercise that seasoned researchers can work around, but thwarts progress ECRs.
Q5.12: I have developed alternative better methodological approaches. A focus narrowly on preregistration is unhelpful for the progress of science.
Q6.12: KCL focuses on a highly centralised/controlled approach to software/hardware, with a focus on non-open Microsoft products. This is often in direct conflict with open software.
Q10.12: Any single set of principles (e.g., gold standards) restrict scientific development. They should at best be used as guidelines.
Q14.12: Getting open access fees paid is almost impossible. I once had to tweet the relevant department to get them to respond to my repeated emails.

EMCRs are completely left to their own devices on this front.
Q2.13: as above. Research services need to go beyond compliance/regs and actually provide practical support for researchers
Q3.12: As with much of these topics the university just see these issues in terms of compliance and monitoring -- not actually engaging with what this might mean. They tend to apply a one size fits all approach rather than look at things on a case by case basis
Q4.12: as previous answers -- the university take a regulatory stance on these things, not a holistic enabling perspective
Q5.12: Registering a research protocol for many academics has become a norm in med sciences, though again it feels like a thing to do/a publication rather than a genuine engagement with what is being said in the publication -- research and good research at that, changes and adapts to circumstances. it is unrealistic to set in stone what you are doing though I appreciate it is the done thing in med sciences.
Q5.13: Much of this is whether we do these things for beureucratic reasons or genuine reasons -- I fear most of this is for the former.

Q12.12: COI again involves politics -- supervisors have vested interests in companies or their own financial interests which are not dealt with well -- the university turn a blind eye to this and if you raise this, they don't want to know because often those supervisors are people with alot of power.

Q9.13: It's common sense to test ad re-test your own data analysis/code and make it available.

Q2.12: I am sorry but I absolutely CANNOT BELIEVE you asked a question about 'legal and ethical' issues then linked ONLY to GDPR!!!!!! This is a HUGE problem in my field and elsewhere where the majority of ethical concerns are being reduced to 'is it GDPR compliant' and even then, most of the time ethics offices and researchers get it very wrong. It is massively stultifying research. Ethics requires consent, data protection should not rely on consent (but legitimate use) and some how the two have become seen as synonymous. Very few researchers use legitimate use as their data processing basis and they really should. And ethics departments have to separate ethics and data regulation or it damages both processes.
Q2.13: This needs serious addressing. Even this survey doesn't understand the issues properly.
Q3.12: Where to start. UKRI is promoting reuse of data which requires it to be prepared and stored for use, but few of the practices of reuse are applied.
Q4.13: People tend to misuse data management plans, where they are used at all. They should be considered as a living document that guides the researcher and then any other users of the data as to what the data is, and how it is/can be used. Instead it is often a fantasy of what data people think will be collected and is not updated enough to reflect reality. But it is rarely built into funding, so is this a surprise?

Q3.1: I am not aware of this
Q3.13: I do not do qualitative research
Q4.12: In my field a large proportion of the research is exploratory so pre-registration is possible to a certain extent but often not based on e.g. effect sizes as in many cases there are no previous studies on which to base predictions/analyses.
Q5.12: Please see my answer to this question on the previous topic.
Q6.12: The risks of using open-source software are similar to those of using proprietary software, i.e., that if an organisation fails then the product(s) won't be available any longer. In addition, getting open-source software installed on one's work computer can be a hassle/difficult/time-consuming/buggy. Using the most updated version of open-source software, even more so!
Q6.13: In my experience, *every* university I've ever worked at has made installing & using open-source software a giant hassle, because of the way university computers are so locked-down. It can be difficult to install new packages (R) or toolboxes. And then if some packages need newer versions of R, getting updated is another headache. I cannot overstate what a horrible stress this has been in my research life. I have taken to using my personal computer to do data analyses out of frustration.
Q7.12: Mostly, the stress of including a silly mistake or typo in one's open analysis code is the biggest barrier (for me).
Q7.13: It can be one thing to "provide the code" to other people, but if one provides code that only works in proprietary software (e.g., SPSS, SAS), it's not very useful. But anyway, it's a start.
Q12.13: Most journals in my field now seem to require authors to declare whether they have conflicts of/competing interests. I have always said I had no conflicts of/competing interests to declare, because I do not make money off of materials that I produce/use.
Q13.13: I never know in which situations it's best to pre-print vs not pre-print a manuscript. I would like some discussions/training on this!
Q14.12: The main barriers of OA are how expensive it is to publish this way, and the restrictions placed by institutions on institutional funding to do so (e.g., must be a minimum 3* paper to get the funding, or corresponding author must be at that institution).
Q14.13: OA is such an important practice, and I appreciate the existence of all the fully open-access journals (PLOS ONE, peerj, Scientific Reports). Especially the gold model of OA feels like such a scam. It's thousands of pounds, and the publishing companies are just skimming that all right off the top, not even paying reviewers a token fee, just holding onto it. Even while institutions are still paying huge subscription fees to get the non-OA content in those journals. Gross.

Q4.12: No risks I am aware of.
Q13.12: There are potential risks to publishing, and barriers to engaging with pre-print work.
Q13.13: Making research openly available is important, but I have never engaged in any research I found on a pre-print server. Nor do I attempt to use pre-print servers. I only engage with that which has been peer reviewed. Otherwise, unless I am willing to spend the time peer reviewing the article myself (in parallel to the journal's due process), then I do not know the quality of the research. This is especially true as many articles I might need to access are not directly in my area of expertise, and I am not best placed to peer review quality (but the results might be important for my work nonetheless). Personally, I think that pre-prints could be counter-productive if not approached very carefully. It would be better to wait until there is an accepted version before sharing author versions of manuscripts (an activity I do engage in).

Q1.7_8_TEXT: Firstly, coproduction is not well understood, definitions are narrow and not well linked into trans- and interdisciplinary research.  Even this survey has a classification scheme that was crude as an ontology for locating my research.  Coproduction is invariably conflated with participative research with communities and citizens and doesn't have the finesse and developments to accommodate wide viewpoints from business and public sector as well.  Happy to elaborate.
Q1.12: Barriers: funding doesn;t pay for coproduction = lip service.  Institution at faculty-level predominantly values traditional domain-based research whilst mitigating this orthodox apporach with some genuine efforts at ID/TDR. Much good intention is thwarted by REF, journal rankings and other reward and recognition practices that fail to acknowledge value of impact, policy engagement and outcomes.  We're obsessed with small measurable, short-term outputs over changing mindsets, processes, delivering long-term beneficial societal outcomes.  We do what we criticise others for doing.
Q1.13: Many but would be too in depth for a survey.
Q2.12: Failure to comply is important particularly around participant data
Q3.12: Access to data is a challenge and typically holds back research.  Commercial companies guard data in urban, infrastructure and so coproducing with private sector and public sector is crucial.  A key barrier is a) either commercial barriers being erected around data ownership even though this data is scraped from the public; b) a public sector run down and withi insufficient capacity to engage witha dn support coproduced research.
Q4.12: I just thnk the training is low grade, unappetising - it's a compliance approach
Q5.7_8_TEXT: Again I'd say there is help.  Training is dull.  The toolsets and process descriptions are cumbersome and arcane. This is something that could be well managed with accessible procedures and supported by toold with a professional audit and learning approach.  I am staggered that Universities don't operate the types of qualty systems found in business, not in a top down obstructive way, but to learn and continually improve.  Big opportunities to improve the academic research processes and practices are missed by a) not having robust and efficient process descriptions; b) investing in tools to support this; and c)auditing to learn and feedback.  Having said that, there are some signs of a change maybe 20 years in arrears of industry!
Q5.12: Just time intensive to check and find out what to do each time and to reinvent tools to manage things.
Q6.12: Time and effort from researchers rather than being supported.
Q7.12: There's limited incentive to share tools, processes and practices except through the medium of writing a paper setting out as yet another framework for....
Q8.12: The barrier is unmaintainable and unusable toolsets.  Reinventing the wheel.  No knowledge capture.  It's all inefficient and unproductive.
Q8.13: I worked in industry (including on quality, security and business continuity systems) for more than my time in university research so non of this is news to me and I am not looking for training. But verstion control in Universities is haphazard to say the least over data, software, hardware, documents or anything else in general.  That's fine up to a point, but then becomes ineficient.  Researchers neet to know when V&V processes add value adn therefore when and where to apply them.
Q9.12: It's not something that has been of major salience for my research to date.
Q9.13: Probably will become more important in future planned research.
Q10.12: I can see this will be important in future research but at this stage has not been a key priority.
Q10.13: I will be looking to ensure such FAIR principles are applied, and in fact data sharing will be a major researhc focus so this will be of interest.  Just not something I have engaged with to date.
Q11.12: External partners in urban areas feel drained by researchers aplyig their research on the communities.  They see data extracted but in some cases little value returned, leading to 'researched fatigue'.
Q11.13: Something I am thinking about and would hope to report on in a paper.
Q12.12: This issue is recognised.  There are some activitiesin raising awareness. I wouldn't say there is a large degree of monitoring and compliance.
Q13.12: It's an activity I haven't explored. Seen others do it. May look into it as a result of this survey.
Q14.12: Just not an agenda item hear that much about on a proactive way.  The facilities are there though.
Q16_11_TEXT: Why one barrier?  These survey questions never quite work for me.  It's many of the above acting in an orchestrated way that thwarts more productive open research.

Q1.12: There are no risks or barriers for adopting open science practices
Q1.13: Crucial component for all scientific fields. No exception.
Q5.12: No excuse not to register studies regardless of the design (I can only provide opinion on medical research)
Q5.13: All researchers (earlier the better, but old hands also need training and behaviour change) to learn about open science practices including importance of registration (particularly outside clinical trials), no excuse not to register for example on the open science framework, protocols, and study materials can all be placed there.
Q6.12: Code (as are all open science practices) is important to share, I see no risks or barriers for sharing code. Sharing code should be the default practice, not the very rare exception.
Q6.13: Perceived barriers are time/money to prepare 'clean'/usable code, but this should be envisaged and planned for upfront. Proprietary issues can be a concern - however, publicly funded research should not be proprietary and should be open source.
Q7.13: None. Just do it. But training needed at an early stage in career as possible. Make it the norm.
Q8.13: Important area, rarely seen in practice (in the field of medical research), code is rarely shared, so version control is even less common.
Q9.12: None. No excuses not to do this.
Q9.13: This should be the norm, no excuses not to.
Q11.13: Should be considered up front, where possible, journals typically have guidelines, but author contributions are often poorly or irresponsibly completed, nobody checks them, and I suspect often fabricated.
Q12.13: Lots of guidance on COIs, but often poorly implemented. And their is no standardisation in the  range/scope of COIs researchers should declare.
Q14.12: Cost (obviously). Lots of unfunded research can not get APC paid for, it's often difficult to get funded research OA, if block grants have run out. Institution wide agreements with publishers (bit like the Dutch system) would help. All research should be OA.
Q14.13: Hugely important but the practice of making research OA is not easy. And care is needed not to widen disparities be that between institutions or within institutions. E.g., proposals (e.g., Hong Kong principles, Moher et al) are great, but if an individual can't afford to pay OA, they shouldn't be penalised, hence there should be parity on access for OA regardless of funding at an institution level

Q3.13: Sharing data should be something that is supported if people wish to engage in it but not something that is expected. Q5.13: For me It is hard to see the usefulness of "pre-registration", especially if you are in a competitive area, where ideas sometimes cannot be share until you have publish your findings. It you as researcher explains how exactly you did your research to anyone (truly) interested in what you are doing, I don't see why you have to say in "advance" what are you planning to do. Perhaps, the people that want to promote this activity should provide clear examples of their usefulness. But these examples should not come only from disciplines working with humans data (e.g. psychology but also from  disciplines working with truly experimental data (e.g. molecular science). Then I will be open to embrace this type of activity.

Q1.12: Co-production has its difficulties when researching particular vulnerable groups (people with mental health/capacity issues).  It is often seen as relevant to the social sciences but not to legal research.
Q1.13: Interdisciplinary research will often involve co-production of research, and we are expected to be knowledgeable about this approach.  However, lawyers are not always trained properly and I have the feeling that we are always playing catch-up!
Q2.12: Difficult to get ethical clearance for high risk projects working with NHS/vulnerable people.  This often require someone on the inside with personal connections.  I don't think our ethics lead is proactive.  We have a blanket ban on students conducting empirical research in their final year dissertation due to the ethical risks and challenges this poses, however in other parts of the University students seem to have much greater scope for this type of work.

However, I think we treat this in bureaucratic terms rather than as an issue of how we understand research practice.

Q4: Lecturer in Neuroscience and Psychology Education
Q5: Phase 2: Early (e.g., Research Associate, first grant holder, Lecturer)
Q1.13: My work on this at the moment is mainly co-produced opinion and commentary pieces to raise awareness of the need for participatory research, focusing on a specific area of research (neurodivergent conditions); myself and my co-authors have lived experience of the topic and we are therefore also raising awareness of the importance of co-production in that sense (making sure to involve researchers with experience of the topic, where possible), as we found that there is a negative bias against researching things that affect us directly (so-called "mesearch") and a misguided perception that one cannot research such topics objectively. The counter-argument to this is that the knowledge produced is also biased, for example by being normative and/or ableist. This is cultural as this is how it has been (and might still be) taught: I was very much taught this positivist view in my own BSc. That being said, a colleague this year introduced our students to work on addiction that is produced by someone with lived experience of it, which shows that things may be starting to shift.
Q2.12: Lack of training opportunities; risk averse nature of higher education institutions
Q2.13: While I haven't looked for training on this specifically, I do see a lot of open science training opportunities through a large number of network, and I have not really seen anything on balancing open science with legal and ethical requirements. I just learnt as I did. I don't think I need to explain the risk averse nature of higher education institutions and ethics committees in the UK :-)
Q3.9: It probably came through the UKRN or COS, maybe RIOT as well (or maybe I attended two webinars on this; the first UKRN network meeting in Aston - in 2019 - also had a good session on this). I don't look specifically for training of any sort, but I am part of many open science networks which allow me to be alerted to a good number of training opportunities.
Q3.13: A number of people don't seem to be convinced this can be done for qualitative work.
Q4.9: Content provided b UCL on their website is quite useful on DMPs. I also did a MSc in Data Science (Loughborough) after I got in my first position, and the Ethics module included a DMP in the assessment.
Q5.12: This topic is one where it is progressing most, I think, partly because it is expected from reviewers / editors (here is your barrier if it still needs actioning).
Q5.13: So my institution takes a passive approach with staff, but the course I teach on actually makes this a core thing. All our BSc students write a form of pre-reg for their dissertation, although it is an internal one, designed for feedback, and there is no guarantee these projects are subsequently preregistered on the OSF or AsPredicted.
Q6.9: As mentioned before, I did a MSc in Data Science (in 2020/21) although I was already in post and 7 years past PhD. My PhD did not involve coding and I felt that this was necessary as part of my Open Science practices: doing a full MSc provided me a structure and goal I needed to commit the time to that training (it also incidentally enabled me to move to my current position, as we teach R at UG level).
Q6.13: Coding is obviously not the only way to move to open source software, people can use jamovi or jasp, which have much less of a time consuming learning curve. But moving to R and Python takes time. Teaching these (R/Python, or even just jamovi/jasp) at UG and PG level is a way to reduce that barrier, but staff then also needs time to change their teaching content. I have found that hiring new staff with these skills (sometimes taking the opportunity offered by a large recruitment drive, such as when many staff have left and need replacing) can be more effective than convincing current staff (e.g., the course we teach R on was opened only three years ago, and staff was recruited specifically to teach on).
Q8.9: Open Science networks serendipitous opportunities again. Self-learning for my MSc Data Science: it was important - and expected for the dissertation project - but we were not formally trained for it.
Q8.13: I think using Open Source software, creating it, and version control all go together (different steps / levels of what are essentially Data Science skills). This one is a bit more advanced, hence it tends to fall through the cracks more. We don't teach proper version control in our BSc either: a lot to teach already), and it is probably more something to include in PhD training.
Q9.9: Again, see OS software answer: Msc Data Science etc
Q9.13: Again, see OS software point: it takes time, so the best way to circumvent this may be to start from the UG level instead of teaching eg SPSS.
Q10.9: This was also discussed in my MSc Data Science (again in the Data Governance & Ethics module)
Q10.13: To apply FAIR principles, computational skills are required, so we are back to the barriers discussed for most recent topics.
Q11.9: Serendipity of what my OS networks offer
Q11.13: Using eg CRediT is not exactly difficult, but I feel awareness is lacking. This is again one where it's the editorial boards who can make a difference, although if people are not aware, they will end up putting together an author statement at the last minute, instead of having the needed discussion at the start of the project. Maybe this could be added to pre-reg forms? Not necessarily filled in advance, but allowing people to declare how they are planning to approach it (just seeing the question would raise awareness).
Q12.13: I think people possibly have a reductive view of what a conflict of interest may be (mainly focusing on commercial conflicts).
Q13.12: Not much , but journals with no pre-print policies are a problem!
Q13.13: I am not sure this needs training beyond raising awareness and using institutional tools (including at publishing level) to change behaviour: depositing a pre-print is relatively simple on its own, while copyright training is probably too dull, so as long as people are informed on the benefits of pre-printing and made aware of Sherpa Romeo, it should be fine.
Q14.12: OA fees, creating equality and diversity issues
Q14.13: Obviously fees can be cancelled for authors in institutions / geographic locations which are under-represented / under-funded, but let's imagine an author whose identities intersection neurodivergence and gender minorities, yet is in a well-funded institutions that may not have an OA fee agreement with a specific publisher: this author would likely seek another journal for their work, maybe reducing exposure. So there is scope for fees support to be more inclusive, with more nuance and more attention to all the different levels of underrepresentation. At institutional level, where HEIs have OA fees agreements, it can add paperwork, so I would also argue for more systematic agreements. Obviously, reforming the publishing industries should also be something we should lobby for (and that is very much a UKRN remit IMO).

Q5: Phase 3: Mid/Recognised (e.g., Senior Lecturer, Reader, Senior Researcher)
Phase 2: Early (e.g., Research Associate, first grant holder, Lecturer)
Q1.12: Universities have a tendency to favour NHS-based projects over primary research, meaning that funding is limited for data-driven outputs and student development. Grants, training and support opportunities are offered to clinicians and medical trainees in favour of career scientists, who split their time between research and clinical duties. Invariably, patient care is prioritised and research gains suffer due to lack of attention, supervision and focus on the part of grant holders. Negative consequences are primarily felt by scientists on fixed term contracts, who bear the burden of responsibility in terms of career progression and financial displacement.
Q1.13: It would be useful to develop some unifying guidelines which bridge the gap between clinical and research laboratory sample handling. Having different operator requirements and limited accessibility to equipment and areas in a laboratory is frustrating.
Q2.12: Time delays are the main barrier. Although the turn around for approval of access to data is timely, composing applications for compliance with individual requirements can be lengthy.
Q2.13: The most frustrating aspect here is a seeming lack of consistency when it comes to compliance guidelines and monitoring. Whilst it is important to avoid any kind of punitive enforcement for non-compliance, it can feel as if efforts are pointless when others benefit from not doing so.
Q4.12: Prior employees have not left comprehensive records, meaning that techniques needed to be re-learned and collected data records cannot be found. This had negative implications for the completion of experiments and has so far prevented a publication from being accepted.
Q4.13: Development of a transparent research culture in a lab needs to be top-down. This can be a problem for labs with a manager or PI working off site - especially if they ignore communication attempts.
Q6.12: Cost and time can be prohibitive for training. Additionally -IT departments are not always proficient in all programs, and do not always have the time to train employees
Q6.13: Some vital analysis software is not open source, and this is an issue for employees and students who do not have access to licences. Although Universities provide these to an extent, they are limited due to misuse. This is a problem - my experience is that (students, particularly)quite often will use pirated copies of licensed software in order to complete projects. If compliance is valued, it would be of use for companies supplying these software programs to facilitate institutional access
Q7.12: I am heavily reliant on the results of software developers in my research, although it isn't my field
Q10.12: Reproducibility is an issue when it comes to time wasted using an unfamiliar technique
Q10.13: I have recently experienced a line manager who considered reproducibility of my data to be non-important, since he believed that a large proportion of published research was non-reproducible.

Q1.12: I think overuse citizen science costs junior academics jobs and opportunities as less menial work needs to be completed by paid professionals. I think over reliance on citizen science to produce knowledge or create impact is unethical but researchers are under pressure to signal 'engagement' and often choose citizen science to do so even if it is not the most appropriate application or even if it results in reduced availability of RA jobs.
Q1.13: In my opinion citizen science should never be used simply to 'save money' - as it often happens for example in the area of digital humanities. The short-term savings will ultimately result in costs to funding and this way academics only advance their own precarity.
Q2.12: There is not enough compulsory training
Q2.13: I believe that it is never a good idea to make participant data available to other researcher as we simply are not able to predict the consequences of this and participants do not typically have sufficient knowledge of computing (e.g. reverse engineering techniques) to understand the potential consequences when consenting to their data by re-used or rendered open source
Q3.12: I would never share qualitative data with other researchers outside of my research group, I consider this unethical and participant consent would not make the practice ethical as participants are not typically able to fully understand the potential risks to their privacy
Q3.13: participant privacy must always be prioritised and come before potential institutional gains
Q4.12: changes to research method can emerge due to unforeseen circumstances and help needs to be given to researchers regarding how to adapt
Q5.13: this is not appropriate with all types of research but could be useful if practices widely - it definitely cannot be placed as another responsibility on individual researchers and if required needs to be designed to be simple and easy for researchers
Q6.12: there is always a fear that is won't be GDPR compliant and I think people lean away from using anything that is not 'standard'
Q8.1: I am not aware of this

Q13.13: there is not enough training available
Q14.13: as usual the burden is placed on individual researchers, one more thing for us to do for which there is no centralised system or solution
Q16_11_TEXT: the system is confusing, the burden is on researchers, it should all be in one place with clear and consistent rules and associated usable software, we cannot be asked to figure everything out ourselves and do another 5 hours of admin per week on top of already overloaded workloads

Q1.12: No risks in particular - just that there's not enough time to do everything.
Q1.13: Some areas of my research lend themselves more to this than others. Clinical studies are well-suited to co-production, but detailed lab research is more difficult. Co-production can help establish the eventual goals of translational research, but maybe not so useful for the detailed protocols or blue skies research.
Q2.7: At the right level,Hard to access
Q2.12: It takes a bit of time to get organised.
Q2.13: It is very important to be open with data, particularly large data sets that are complex to acquire.
Q4.12: No risks (except another pressure on time).
Q4.13: It is very important to be organised with data. It should be mandatory from the outset of all PhDs to develop a DMP.
Q5.12: There is a risk that competitors could publish quickly if they see another study is being done in the area.
Q5.13: It's very important in some areas, e.g. clinical trials and systematic reviews. It is not so useful for lab research, where the experimental plan has to be flexible to respond to each finding as it happens.
Q6.12: It can be complex to learn open source software.
Q6.13: It is important to some areas of my research (e.g. bioinformatics and image analysis) since there is a need to tune the software to different scientific questions.
Q7.12: I just don't have time to do this.
Q7.13: It needs specialists to do this.
Q8.12: It is important that everyone can use the same protocols.
Q8.13: It is important as part of good data management.
Q9.1: I am not aware of this

Q9.13: Not important to my own research, but I am aware of the importance as I collaborate with people who develop code.
Q10.13: It is important to share data and standards. However, the standards are always changing and some bodies require too much, which is a barrier to compliance due to the time involved.
Q12.12: There's a big risk from not complying. However, I worry that revealing too much about collaborations with industry could be counterproductive too.
Q12.13: It is not always clear-cut and it would be useful to have more training.
Q13.12: I have heard of cases where publication was denied as a pre-print had been published a long time earlier. There's a danger of false messages getting out with pre-prints (seen with COVID-19 papers).
Q13.13: I have mixed feelings about the benefits of early release vs the dangers of lack of peer review. If it's done right, it can work well.
Q14.12: There's an inherent danger in the OA model where author pays publication fees and journals make money per paper. This incentivises journals to publish everything they can.
Q14.13: I agree with the principle that science should be freely accessible, but I worry about the incentives for publication. There's a danger scientific rigour may be lost.

Q1.13: co-production is not relevant to the majority of lab-based research
Q2.12: Requires resources (both time and money) that are not always considered by the institution or the grant providers. Specifically data curation and sharing is extremely time consuming, and should be done by dedicated personal other than the junior research staff, as it does not (and should not!) contribute to their professional development towards independence.
Q2.13: Very important for academia to stay relevant in the modern world, but needs to be established as a core management process with dedicated staff, see my comment above.
Q3.12: There's a big knowledge and awareness gap in this area, including in the senior levels, who have not used modern data processing techniques themselves and unaware of the considerations regarding proper documentation and sharing of code. This usually falls on personal practices of junior researchers, with supervision typically geared towards compliance with journal minimal requirements.
Q3.13: Very important, see my comment above.
Q4.12: This is a very time-consuming task, and researcher are very likely to start gathering preliminary data, then skip this phase and go ahead to for the full experiment (often incorporating the preliminary data as well). It's difficult to consider when is the appropriate stage to formulate such a plan (before or after preliminary data), but those stages of research are fast-paced, and rarely there's time to stop and formulate such a plan, unless required to do so, or actively monitored by a dedicated staff (who leads this discussion, and helps making provisions for its implementation).
Q4.13: See above. I don't thinks this is likely to happen on a regular basis in most labs, unless led by a dedicated staff responsible for data dissemination.
Q5.13: not very relevant to my field, I'm not much familiar with it.
Q6.12: there are some knowledge gaps, in all levels
Q6.13: this happens constantly, and I think there's more room to share knowledge on using open source software, how to get support, report issues and decide which software to use.
Q7.12: Training is badly needed, and external support as well. Also, software and open source code needs to be maintained, and this is a task unsuitable to the temporary nature of junior researchers.
Q8.12: Very little awareness and knowledge on this topic in academia
Q9.12: Almost no knowledge about it, even if the importance is recognised
Q9.13: Very important subject, with almost no training for best practices or requirements from institutions, grants or publishers.
Q12.13: not important, purely a formality in most cases I've encountered.
Q13.13: Not a big fan of pre-prints. The review process does make for a much better final product.
Q14.12: Costs involved, and prestige from non-open access journals.
Q16_11_TEXT: Lack of dedicated personnel. This would solve the lack of incentives, time and interest from junior (and senior) researchers.

Q1.12: co- publication is very important in research. Working together on a goal is much more efficient than working as individuals. I believe conferences are my main opportunity to find others that are interested in working together.
Q1.13: I believe the passive approach is fine as long as people are aware of where they can go to seek further advice and support if they need it.
Q2.12: I feel that I am reliant on my supervisor to advice for publication in open research journals. However, further support from the University is certa.inly available if I wish to seek out a specific journal
Q2.13: very important, in my opinion all research should be free to access for the greater good.
Q3.12: The risk with a passive approach at the university are minimised by thorough peer reviewing in journal articles.
Q3.13: We often use Fiji/imageJ to get basic quantifications of our qualatative results to support them. This is a useful approach and gives more transparancy to the results.
Q4.12: data management is very important. The eeward of thorough research and organisation is enough to encourage me to continue doing it.
Q4.13: Without data management scientific research gets very very messy. Usually sophisticated tools are not required, but spending  time on organisation is critical.

Q6.13: The library is an excellent location for spread of open research.

Q8.12: This approach is fine as long as the researchers are aware of its importance and take care when organising and lebellinv data.
Q8.13: Simply naming, dating and adding a version number has been adiquate in my limited experience.

Q10.12: Having  inaccessible data is useless, so its improtamt not just to the others but the researcher themself.

Q11.12: As a junior researcher, there is a chance of being left out of a paper or not getting the aknowledgements I deserve. Although generally researchers are happy to aknowlege my help.
Q11.13: It is important to discuss the rankings of authors and agree BEFORE starting ro write the paper.
Q12.12: Failure to highlight conflict of interest is not the end of the world, however it does increase the risk of falsified results.

Q13.13: Pre- prints are nice and a good way to increase awareness of your project, but I dont think they are critical.
Q14.12: Publications without open access can be very frustrating, however the library is good at obtaining closed articles that may be critical.
Q14.13: Closed articles are a major off put. If they are not easy to access I most likely will not read them and look.for other research first.

Q5: Phase 2: Early (e.g., Research Associate, first grant holder, Lecturer)
Q1.12: It is ethically problematic and exploitative.
Q1.13: There is very little awareness for the importance of complying with research ethics and by this I mean the practical implications rather than the written guidelines, which most academic end up not complying with. The academic environment enables practices that would typically be considered unethical and it becomes "normal and acceptable because everyone else does it". The "grant culture" has facilitated this a lot.
Q2.12: It does potentially cause unethical practices, exploitation of researchers and of the researched, and data protection issues.
Q2.13: One example is a practice that is common in field research: conducting research in a foreign country or location that is unfamiliar to the research. One of the many challenges they face is language barrier, which is in itself an ethical concern that foster bias, at times colonial reproduction (not just north-south but also south-south). Another challenge is the length of the field work and the usage of gatekeepers who are one-sided or representative a small portion of society and the context of research - this in in turn creates power relations that often cause more problems than they contribute to creating "social impact", which is what academic research claims to advertise. Researchers then use this in return for seeking more grants and building a PR image. Another common problem especially in settings where the leading researcher is unfamiliar with the context of research is outsourcing. When research is outsourced to less senior yet more informed persons, a lot of issues arise: abuse of the main researcher's power, poor research, and exploitation (of both the subjects of research but also of the leading field researchers). These issues are not being tackled enough because of the way the industry is being led and evolving with lack of government funding and de-prioritising of education and research sectors (leading to them being outsourced to big donors who impose their own agendas, in very similar ways to big corporations).

Q5.12: It is very important to raise awareness on this practice as it might be a way to protect data and IP. I had not been aware of this before, presumably due to lack of training and discussions around it.

I am sure the support is available, and the courses on the topic have been good, but perhaps I am just unaware of it.
Q4.13: It would be good to make researchers (particularly juniors who have not had as many years of networking) aware of the support available for qualitative and quantitative data analysis and design.

Q11.12: It is widely known in this industry that junior researchers are often instructed/influenced regarding, for example, who to include for authorship on a paper, even if that person has not had a lot of input. This can be hard to push against when beginning your career and others are in a position of authority and can heavily influence your path.
Q11.13: If the University felt this was important, perhaps some mandatory training for superiors and/or campaigning on the power that those in authority hold.
Q12.12: None. I think all of the researchers I work(ed) with are very transparent when it comes to conflicts of interest.
Q13.13: In the field of medical research I do feel this is important for the research which could influence e.g. clinical outcomes, however, my own research is not of this nature. The wait for publication, I believe, would not be a significant loss.
Q14.12: Main barriers to open access is the cost. As a junior you're not always aware of the funding available to you, as a lot of the journals we look to publish in are outside of the open-access contracts our library has with certain journals.
Q14.13: I think it is becoming very common now for major research funders to have policies that fund open-access publications or for researchers to build it into their costs in their applications. My own research is not funded by a major research funder. I have supportive supervisors who have found funds for me to publish open access. Perhaps there should be more support for this for those researchers not funded by regular/large funding bodies.

Q6.13: I use computer algebra packages that specialize in group theory: there are two or three big ones one Open Source and one (or more) paid.  Usually I cannot afford the license for the paid one.  Only pure mathematicians will use these packages, so it would be hard to justify the University spending lots of money on them when the Open Source ones are usually pretty good.

Q14.12: From my time in industry I know that the cost of journals can be a significant barrier to accessing research output.
Q14.13: IEEE journals were always low-cost to members and so have high impact among a community that uses the science but does not publish and cite the science. Hence academic measures of "impact" may not reflect real world "usefulness" of publications. Journal availability became a more significant issue to non-academics when library holding became electronic. It was no longer sufficient to be an external member of the University Library to access the physical stacks.

Q1.12: Laboratory-based molecular research has barriers based on necessary experience, including those relating to health and safety, which requires a degree of background knowledge
Q1.13: ' Outsourcing' data analysis to citizen scientists has been overtaken by cheap computing and AI, leaving practical laboratory work. Deeper analysis of data requires specialist knowledge.
Q2.7: Too basic,I do not know,Other. Please explain:
Q2.7_8_TEXT: There are too many different pulls in terms of what different disciplines require, and we need a more decentralised system, but there is no funding for this (would require one FTE)
Q2.12: Some science is 'closed' for a while due to IP, but everything needs to be open at the time of publication (preprint first).
Q2.13: Very few methods are truly reproducible due to closed science - we should have funding, a mandate and recognition for depositing methods in protocols.io
Q3.13: It is critical - REF papers for example should have a mandate for full protocols at e.g., protocols.io. I note that systems where protocol can be accessed via the authors, as found at Science are NOT open.
Q4.13: There needs to be monitoring and reward.
Q8.12: Barrier is cost - no funding for this. The usual pass the parcel between Research Councils (who say FEC is for this) and Universities (who point out FEC only covers 80% of costs). When a grant is ended, there is no funding to maintain its 'outputs', be they code or reagents.
Q9.12: Barrier is maintaining code when funding ends.
Q9.13: The consequence is much generated code is 'lost' and people then reinvent the wheel
Q10.12: The usual funding barrier interns of painting and regenerating materials for others to use.
Q11.13: No monitoring - the area if fraught with 'politics' and will continue to be so when the reward system (REF, promotion etc.) is skewed to the journal and not the content of the article.
Q13.13: A cultural shift has yet to take place. I preprint all papers where I have editorial control, but this is far from universal.
Q14.12: The only risk is pandering to 'glamour' and wasting money, when there are excellent non for profit publishers
Q14.13: Ban OA in for profit journals, and only allow in learned Society and non for profit.

Q1.1: I am not aware of this

Q2.12: I am keen to embrace open research practices. It enhances my field of study.
Q2.13: The main advantage of data sharing is that if forces researchers to tidy up all materials before publication
Q3.1: I am not aware of this
Q3.12: Uni of Liverpool is trying to encourage open research practices, for both qual and quant researchers.
Q3.13: Qual interviews not my field - can't comment on this much.
Q4.12: I have never done a formal data managment plan, but in my lab we have norms about pre-registration, data processing, and data archiving on OSF
Q4.13: There is a risk of open science becoming burdensome and full of red tape. There is clearly room for improvement, and this will involve researchers adopting new proceedures, but I don't think, for example, mandatory data management plans are a good idea. This kind of thing encourages letter of the law behaviour. Unless people embrace the spirit of open science, its not useful.
Q5.12: In my lab we have very much embraced pre-registration, for example, on as predicted.org. This is vaguely encouraged in my university, but probably not widely adopted.
Q5.13: This is very important to my field and personal practice. Again we have a letter of the law/spirit of the law clash. Mandatory causes letter of the law behaviour, which stops people embracing the spirit. People who don't want to embrace the spirit of pre-registration are probably beyond redemption anyway.
Q6.12: Open source software, such as EEG lab, Psychopy, R, JASP and various libraries and toolboxes are essential to my field of study.
Q6.13: This seems like an incoherent question. It is impossible to imagine anyone being about to do anything without open source software in my field.
Q7.12: There are risks in terms of professional vulnerability. If you make software, you risk others using it warts and all.
Q7.13: I'm not sure I would call it 'making open source software' but our analysis codes are on Github. This is important for our lab.
Q8.12: I haven't specifically engaged with version control.
Q8.13: This is important, and something I will need to do more in future.
Q9.12: There are risks to not ensuring computational reproducibility.
Q9.13: This is absolutely essential. I think it needs to be encouraged more at University of Liverpool.
Q10.12: People feel professional vulerability if others can double check their data.
Q10.13: I have gone a long way towards this with my data archiving program. Making a FAIR catalogue is very improtant for me.
Q11.12: Arguments about authorship and inclusion can be problematic
Q11.13: Establishing authorship order can be tricky. Worst is when projects evolve and contributions change in unexpected ways.
Q12.12: Never been an important topic in my sub-field.
Q12.13: We all have some conflict of interest - some data patterns are better for our careers than others.
Q13.12: I'm usure about the open science value of pre-prints. We can a half finished manuscript that can be searched before peer review. These draft echos on the internet are not useful.
Q13.13: I'm not a fan of pre-prints. Can be good to make null results visible to meta analysis
Q14.12: Very few costs to making papers open access.
Q14.13: I can't believe we still gift so much money to Elsevier! Once to publish open access, once more to pay for subscription.

Q1.12: Why (and how!?) would patients or other non-research trained stakeholders be invovled in biomedical research? We are trained (to PhD) level to understand and carry out research. Q2.12: Yes there are numerous risks in the bioemdical field, and the University of Liverpool has zero interest in addressing it in any meaningful way. As is typical, the senior leadership team pays lip-service here (focusing on NSS scores and spinning REF returns instead!). We see the shameful results of this from fraudelent research published from University (e.g. Dan Antoine) and highly dubious work published (e.g. Macchiarini P, et al.  Lancet2008;372:2023-30.) linked to patient deaths.

Q8.9: Partner who is a software programmer, colleague

Q10.9: see previous answer to  similar question
Q10.12: I am trying to do my best to adhere to the FAIR principles but don't have anyone to check whether my output is fully compliant.
Q10.13: One of the biggest bottlenecks are data repositories to make the image data openly available on which the workflow is based.
Q11.12: There is no monitoring (impossible) and no recognition. the only approach is: If you use the facility, please acknowledge. If this is not done, there are no repercussions. Monitoring is done by facility staff off their own back, who have other jobs to do.
Q11.13: It is difficult to navigate the mindset: If I pay for a service, why should I also acknowledge the facility? The majority of users are acknowledging the facility but not all.
Q13.12: Pre-prints are not counting for REF exercises and that is the be all and end all it seems.
Q13.13: Still too much emphasis on publishing in high impact factor journals...
