Q5: Phase 4: Established/Experienced (e.g., Professor, Principal Fellows or Scientists)
Q1.12: Misunderstandings of data protection and similar regulation; failure to understand what "informed consent" means for the participant (and why it's confusing); risk aversion; condescending approach to participants
Q1.13: We have a primary responsibility to our research participants irrespective of public funding. So often, they are bottom of the pile when it comes to establishing appropriate practices. Research should (IMHO) be based on trust and negotiation, not meaningless PIS and CF
Q2.7_8_TEXT: Unresourced
Q2.9: Appropriate agencies (e.g., HRA); ESOC; my professional bodies (BPS, BCS)
Q2.12: As previously stated, there is no understanding of what research and research participation really means. To be fair, government and government agencies don't understand what the regulatory frameworks shoudl be to enable appropriate engagement.
Q2.13: It's hugely frustrating; and the general approach is "No, you can't..." as opposed to "Well, how can we make this happen, if it's the right thing..."
Q3.12: (1) Respect for participant wishes (a) their prosociality; but also (b) longevity of data retention. (2) Anonymisation / pseudonymisation for qualitative research is almost too damaging
Q3.13: There is a general misunderstanding that "ethics" means "privacy", and so all efforts go on mitigating the risk of re-identification. There is no respect for individuals and the validity of their input, engagement and perspectives
Q4.12: N/A - though a DMP is not a DPIA; it's about appropriate management of data and understanding its lifecycle.
Q4.13: As above - too much attention on regulation, not enough on what we are trying to achieve. There's also an insidious feeling that researchers certainly are becoming fatigued by what they see as 'tick box' constraints rather than admin support for their work
Q5.12: People focus on 'value' in terms of p values (which is anathema to qualitative research anyway), but this means published work is biased, and we fail to learn from others
Q5.13: Should be encouraged wherever possible - it's about open science after all
Q6.12: This is about 'reputation' - doing stats with R is perceived somehow as better than with, e.g., IBM SPSS. That's nonsense, of course
Q6.13: If reproduceability is the goal, then that should be the focus, not some spurious reputational deal
Q7.12: My understanding here is about reproduceability. The onus is probably on peer reviewers to check. My approach is very much about being explicit about how I've arrived at my results.
Q7.13: I support the notion of Open Science and collaborative research; but I'm wary of anything which becomes a constraint
Q9.9: *WHEN DOING QUANTIATIVE RESEARCH*, then I always look for help from, e.g, YouTube (!), tutorials, some CPD type course
Q9.12: This is only applicable to quantitative methods. There are different mechanisms in qualitative research
Q9.13: So many colleagues don't understand how qual methods work or what the processes are to support research findings. It would be nice to have this acknowledged occasionally!
Q10.9: Sort of... via UK Data Services
Q10.12: Bound up with limitations and barriers by misunderstanding regulation, but also, now, there is growing focus on TREs in research. If we're not careful, we'll miss the views of the research participants... again
Q10.13: FAIR principles are only one part of this story; we need to think about the CARE principles (cf. the RDA guidance here)
Q11.12: I am very suspicious of articles with a cast of thousands as authors; I'm also extremely unhappy by how many 'co-authors' appear on my work.
Q11.13: COPE doesn't really seem to be working, in my experience
Q12.12: My experience here is that this is a tick-in-the-box exercise only; it's part of reflexivity in qual research, of course, *that's* a major factor for me. Other conflicts, like the source of funding, is not really an issue in my area
Q12.13: The government should keep out of University business (cf. the Manchester case recently where we had some parlimentarians questionning what money is spent on for Mary Whitehouse type reasons)
Q13.12: Tends to come down to the 'rules' of the publisher
Q13.13: Proper researcher open-access should be available. APCs are detrimental to research
Q14.12: This is about money, aka APCs. It's so destructive, and potentially damaging for ECRs and those working in slightly esoteric areas
Q14.13: In my experience, you spend too much time trying to make some spurious link between perfectly decent research and a funding source (which may well have been fixed in advance). Where is the provision for supporting research based on its peer-reviewed quality rather than the financial acumen of someone who muscles in on the co-author list?
Q16_11_TEXT: It's a combination of lack of funding and lack of support for truly exploratory research. Pity

Q1.13: With NIHR funding he topic is 'hard wired' into the research process to a large extent - consequently the passive institutional approach reflects that it is pretty much 'business as usual'
Q2.12: Significant regulatory hurdles to undertaking any research. Some absolutely necessary, some overly complex. Negotiating internal mechanisms to access support / ensure compliance is painful.
Q3.13: There appears to be much less focus and concern about transparency in qualitative data analysis /research
Q5.12: There is increasing concern about discrepancies between protocols and publication - understanding the purpose of registration and plans and the significance of non alignment is often poorly understood, but increasingly likely to have consequences.
Q5.13: There is a tension between advance specification (important) and the ability to undertake exploratory research. I am not sure if we really know how to reconcile the two competing imperatives
Q6.13: I am unsure what the focus of the question about open source software as a topic should be. What are my training needs for this topic, as opposed to a particular piece of software? I don't know - which may reflect a significant knowledge gap.
Q8.12: The increasing requirement to make data available and analyses reproducible makes this a more important issue - potential risks include not being able to publish
Q8.13: Day to day access and familiarity with the tools for the job here are low and 'manual' practices are risky (and haphazardly applied)
Q10.12: State of the art / expectations are moving on and there is a risk that some may be left behind
Q11.13: There are cultures of extremely poor practice out there and a danger that this shapes the expectations of upcoming generations
Q13.12: As posting pre-prints is not universally accepted by publishers some channels of publication can be inadvertently blocked
Q13.13: While well established in other disciplines it feels relatively new for us - I am trying to establish it as routine practice but have had to learn and accept the consequences and risks (see above)
Q14.13: It is now very much 'business as usual' for many although the complexities are not well understood by many (e.g. 'flavours' of OA, licensing requirements / issues)

Q2.12: My previous research field (psychology) is further ahead on open science than my current field (public health). I have found our ethics committee very hesitant to approve anonymised open data and I have had to limit access to some of my datasets as a result

Q4.13: Our ethics committee requires DMPs, which I think is very helpful to ensure that all projects have one in place before they commence
Q5.12: There is a risk to preregistering data analysis plans for publicly available data and not very clear guidance on what to do if you have already analysed the dataset for other questions in the past
Q5.13: In my previous field, preregistration appears to be the norm and I have received sufficient training to undertake it. Q5: Phase 4: Established/Experienced (e.g., Professor, Principal Fellows or Scientists)
Q1.12: The risks in the area I particularly work in are not high, because the co-producers are frequently in quasi-academic roles (institutes where pure research is also done alongside applied work), so practitioners are familiar with academic conventions.
Q1.13: My personal approach to this has simply been to give practitioners a high degree of involvement in shaping the research goals and outputs. I have not had formal training in this.
Q2.12: In my specific field, risks are low, but in other areas of the discipline they are potentially much higher.
Q2.13: Researchers should have a degree of knowledge in this area that encompasses their wider discipline, because it helps us to be able to supervise MA/PhD students who may work in slightly different areas.
Q3.12: There are a lot of requirements imposed by funders - failure to live up to them can result in sanctions.
Q3.13: We get an awful lot of material about this, but it's mostly then on us to ensure we read and comply. There is training available, but courses are not frequent.
Q4.12: We need DMPs for compliance purposes and to ensure we've thought through the implications of our work - failure to do them well will result in failure to get a grant or exposing us to risk of data loss.
Q4.13: My institution provides very good support in the writing of DMPs. I think this is probably better than generic training, as fields are so different that I wouldn't get much from sitting alongside a chemist, medic and economist in a training session....
Q5.12: Pre-registration is difficult but not risky.
Q5.13: This is a relatively new development in my field but one that is becoming more popular.
Q6.6: Infrequent,At too complex a level,At too basic a level
Q6.12: I don't think we do a very good job of training - courses are very infrequent and therefore oversubscribed. We don't have a deep talent pool of researchers with expertise, so it is down to our IT services team to supply training. They are very good but overstretched.
Q6.13: We have excellent support one-on-one for staff; I'd especially commend the staff statistician, who is an excellent resource.
Q7.12: It's useful to be able to do this; the risk is that if you don't, you're dependent on others developing software that may or may not suit your needs.
Q7.13: I'd have loved to do this earlier in my career - but it needs a critical mass of involved staff in the area and this has not been the case in my field here for a long time.
Q8.12: Version control has real risks if you confuse different iterations of your data - valuable information can be lost and you may report on incomplete results.
Q8.13: I think this is probably not one for training courses, but for suggested reading and/or collaborative discussions/workshops.
Q9.12: This is an expectation that is growing in my field. Non-reproducible results are looked on with some suspicion and it's harder to publish them than it was a few years ago.
Q9.13: It would be interesting to work directly with some repositories in my field to learn more about their requirements.
Q10.12: This is a fundamental requirement of research in the field these days - there's a risk in not being taken seriously if you don't follow these principles.
Q11.12: There is a risk in not recognizing contributors.
Q11.13: I have not worked with researchers who wish to have their specific contributions enumerated, although I do occasionally see this in reviewing and reading journal articles.
Q12.12: There are substantial risks in this if they're overlooked.
Q12.13: This is mainly a matter of common sense and application: read the guidelines given, query if necessary, err on the safe side to avoid problems.
Q13.12: There is some risk to this, I guess, but no more than other forms of open publication.
Q14.12: It's necessary to comply with OA rules for grants.
Q14.13: I have some worries about the sorts of OA licences now required, but time will tell if these CC-BY licences cause problems with work being reproduced in altered form and outside the contexts for which it was intended.

Q5: Phase 4: Established/Experienced (e.g., Professor, Principal Fellows or Scientists)
Q1.12: Why is this a compulsory question?  It starts with "If", which implies that it is not compulsory, but the survey won't let me move on till I've answered it.
Q1.13: I'm assuming that "research co-production" means research in collaboration with others.  This is universal in my field of experimental particle physics.  I've never felt that it needed specific training.
Q2.7_8_TEXT: It's one-size-fits-all.  One size does not fit all.  Different disciplines operate very differently.
Q2.12: There was an issue when they weren't accepting arXiv as open access.  Nobody seemed to grasp that in a large collaboration the decision as to where to publish generally does not rest with the individual.
Q2.13: Open access to papers and results is standard practice in my field.  Open access to raw data is much, much harder - I wouldn't know how to do it in any meaningful way.
Q4.12: Data management has always been important in particle physics - it's why the WWW was invented!
Q4.13: Again, one-size-fits-all approaches are not very useful.  We are an international collaboration with centrally managed data and code.  Expecting people to draw up individual data management plans is not sensible.
Q5.13: Formal pre-registration does not happen in my field - we're not conducting clinical trials.  However, "blind analyses" where the selection procedure, analysis protocol, etc., are defined using simulations before looking at the data is standard practice.  It just doesn't involve formal, external pre-registration.
Q6.13: Experimental particle physics relies completely on shared code, whether this is formally open-source such as GEANT4 or only open-source within the collaboration (e.g. common software for reconstructing tracks, identifying particles, calculating systematic errors, etc.).  So it's not in any sense a "risk" or a "barrier" - on the contrary, it is essential.  Training, instruction manuals etc. (of, it must be admitted, variable quality) are organised within the collaboration.  It's not clear that centralised training would be effective, except possibly for aspects of code sharing that are widely used by different disciplines, e.g. github for version control.
Q7.13: See previous comment - code sharing is essential in my field, everyone does it, training (where necessary) is generally provided within collaboration.
Q8.13: Much the same as before.  Version control is critical to experimental particle physics - for example, we are currently on production 6T of the standard data reduction (the basic track reconstruction, particle ID etc. that everyone uses), and the parameters (and sometimes the format) do change from production to production.  All collaborations use some form of version control (we use github), but details of implementation will be experiment specific, so training is best done within the collaboration.  I don't really think that a one-size-fits-all university training scheme would be very useful.
Q9.13: Much the same comments as before.  Reproducibility is essential, but is readily tested - for example, we have three separate analysis teams working with different code for our main flagship analysis, and nothing gets published until all three results are consistent; new software versions are validated against the previous version to ensure that the same calculations yield the same result; the effects of varying selection procedures or details of analysis are checked and included in the systematic error budget.  Particle physicists are much more savvy about statistics now than they were 40 years ago when I started.
Q10.12: It doesn't really, within collaborations, but interoperability in the sense of enabling joint analysis of data from different experiments is a challenge.  That's the nature of the beast - it's not due to bad practice on anyone's part.
Q10.13: Within collaborations, FAIR is the rule: data have to be findable and accessible to all of the hundreds (my experiment) or thousands (ATLAS and CMS) of collaborators spread around the world, and analysis code has to be (reasonably) interoperable ("reasonably", in that a certain degree of commonality is expected - particle physics analyses are generally done on a Linux platform, and we would not expect the standard software to work on Windows, Mac and Android).  Some code - for example, the simulation package GEANT4, and the analysis, data management and plotting environment ROOT - need to be more widely interoperable, in that they are used by many (nearly all) collaborations.  Trying to develop a portable data format that would allow different experiments to share data, as opposed to processed results, is much harder - though attempts have been made (and my PhD student led one of them).
Q11.12: It is actually a risk.  Experimental particle physics has always had a very inclusive approach to authorship - anyone who contributed to acquiring the data being analysed is an author, regardless of whether they were involved in the specific analysis being reported (the same data are analysed in a multitude of different ways and lead to many publications).  This is, I think, essential to the success of large collaborations.  There are always some people whose principal contribution is keeping the experiment running and maintaining good data quality.  If only the people specifically involved in a particular analysis were named as authors on the corresponding paper, those people would have to spend part (most?) of their time doing analysis, and everyone would suffer as a result.  With apologies to John Milton, "they also serve who only stand and calibrate."
Q12.12: Conflicts of interest rarely arise in my field, except as it pertains to national fellowship schemes: particle physics is not a discipline where there is external pressure to obtain specific results.  I think there are sometimes conflicts of interest at the level of policy setting (for example, the need to be seen to be getting "value for money" for the CERN subscription has, I think, sometimes led to CERN-based experiments being prioritised above what might be justified purely on physics grounds), but that's well above my pay grade.
Q13.13: Particle physicists (and astronomers) are obsessive users of the arXiv preprint server.  It's just a given that any papers produced by the collaboration are released on arXiv.  Some journals in the field (especially the increasing number of online-only journals) actually expect an arXiv submission, and will pick up the manuscript from arXiv.
Q14.7_8_TEXT: ...not very useful, because everyone in the field has been using arXiv since its inception.  It was useful earlier, when for some reason arXiv wasn't considered adequate as "open access" submission (which I never understood), but it's become less so now that common sense has prevailed.
Q14.13: See above.  Particle physicists have been using open-access preprint repositories for as long as they have existed.
Q16_11_TEXT: It depends on your definition.  Open access publications are ubiquitous.  Open access to processed results has become so over the last decade or so.  Open access to raw data is, in my opinion, not realistically possible.  To provide open access to data from a particle physics experiment, you would need to provide: (1) the data themselves (presumably as reconstructed tracks, not real raw data), (2) information about triggers, data quality, reconstruction efficiency, systematic errors, resolution, etc. (3) appropriate simulations for any analysis the consumers of the open data want to carry out (including information about associated systematic errors), (4) enough documentation for outsiders (unfamiliar with the experiment, and with no access to the experts on particular subsystems) to be able to use the data sensibly and in accordance with its limitations.  This is not practicable.  ATLAS has invested a huge amount of effort in producing "ATLAS Open Data" - and they have succeeded in producing something that is designed for educational purposes, so that students can get some impression of how particle physics is done.  It definitely is NOT a tool that a non-ATLAS person could use to do a rigorous physics analysis.  Smaller collaborations don't really have the resources to manage even that much.

Q5: Phase 2: Early (e.g., Research Associate, first grant holder, Lecturer)
Q1.12: My field is conducting economic evaluations of medical studies. Coproduction of research is undertaken when designing the underlying study, although this is conducted by others. If we were to do coproduction of the economic evaluation there is an objectivity risk. It is just as important to find what is economically beneficial as well as what is not.
Q2.9: The key thing in my field would be open access analysis code. I looked at websties describing the nature of software open access licences
Q3.1: I am not aware of this
Q3.12: None. My research is not qualitative
Q4.12: Data management plans do need to change. The problem is that they are completely seperate from research services and we often reuse IP. As such they are merely of intent and have very little impact on projects. If data managment were more tightly integrated into the research contract process, then they could become a more useful tool in research.
Q5.12: Yes this is a big risk, if we prespecify everything in detail. My field involves making the best prediction over a lifetime. Prespecifying this before any evidence is available could lead to bad science and bad head line conclusions. The opposite end of spectrum is a protocol that states and economic analysis will be conducted and what evidence is needed. This is OK and achievable but it is a bit useless.
Q6.9: Online, particularly around what licence terms actually meant
Q6.12: Given our work effectively involves developing software. We should move this way. Therefore having training on how to make out software open access and how to use other people's open access software woudl be good. Data management plans could become useful if there was an intergration with research service teams to check the legal standing of making software open source, and whether using exisitng open source software required further publishing.
Q7.9: Online, about licenec terms. Emailed deparmtental contacts about open sourcing code/software
Q7.12: Risks are that we are generally solo developers (as this is what funders will pay for),  and this could expose errors. However, this is the right thing to do and might convince funders to hire software development teams rather than individuals.
Q8.12: THe risk is that we do not learn how to use git effectively. To do this we need training, which currently does not exist at the university level. .
Q9.12: THe only risk, would be to be fully reproducible, it may be the case that someone needs access to confidential data (e.g. small age groups, n <5) to run our analyses. Q3.13: There is little to no qualitative research required in my specific field (engineering). Any non-quantitive suggestions made in a published work are backed by citing work where quantitive data is available.
Q5.13: Preregistration is not a concept I have come across in my field. From the definition provided, preregistration can include an embargo period. Typically my field, work is published in a journal, and the data used in the paper is included in a repository (if the particular group or institute in question decides to publish the data). The only time an embargo has been used is on publishing a PhD thesis to a repository (e.g. white rose), where some results chapters have not yet been published or are in the process of being drafted for publication. The embargo is typically 1 year
Q6.13: Software is cited in any work with link to respository of the orignal code/program if possible.
Q9.12: The main obstacle for me is commercial partners not wishing to disclose key information about an experimental device structure for fear of copies. I find the argument usually invalid as the main two layers in the structure can be inferred from multiple standard measurements and measured from another standard measurement. Without these standard measurements, the more complex measurements (typically the reason for publishing) become meaningless, as no comparison can be made with other devices. However, the required data can not be included due to the research partners' reservations. Hence the paper is not submitted for publication or is rejected by the reviewers (rightly so in my opinion) as the data is incomplete and unrepeatable.
Q9.13: Very important in my field where we characterise novel devices and simulate devices. All too often, there is missing key information in a journal article making replication of simulated results or experimental data impossible. Typically such papers would be rejected by reviewers; however, many papers slip through, muddying the research field with ambiguous data.
Q10.13: All data used in a publication is submitted to Figshare/ORDA. where it is checked by library services that the file types are correct (txt, csv etc and not a Proprietary file type). Published papers are also uploaded to white rose (open acess data), ensuring to comply with any copyright restriction placed on the manuscript by a journal publisher.

Q1.13: I research with students, and I feel they should be much more involved in the research as partners. I also feel that we should be using the evidence base we have to make data driven decisions rather than those based on custom and practice.  In addition we need to move away from the broken system of  arbitrarily dividing people up by sex, ethnicity and age and using this to get published as significant research (p>.05) and more towards broader findings. â for example the questionnaire finds a difference between men and women â how are you going to change practices as a result? We need to start with research design and think about what we are measuring and why.

Q2.13: the university should provide more training to researchers in other areas, for example I recently reviewed ethics for a study and suggested some changes based on ethical principles to which they withdrew the application and just did it without ethics! Q1.12: I learn about coproduction through colleagues and students who have tried and critically review this approach. The risks/ barriers relate to the funding process and grant writing which preclude meaningful engagement with participants & sometimes collaborators at a very early stage. The funding models also make coproduction really tricky - getting funding to participants or collaborators unless they are written in as co-investigators.
Q1.13: I wouldn't describe myself as someone who fully uses coproduction but someone who uses it in some of my work - it also depends whether you mean coproduction with fellow academics, research participants or interested organisations  / individuals. I collaborate with colleagues in my research projects and have recently completed a more collaborative project with participants.
Q2.9: from collaborators in other instutions outside of the UK. I am not sure what you mean by open research - this question needs better phrasing or breaking down so we can respond to what aspects of training you might be inferring. Eg ethics / data management / publication agreements with collaborators
Q2.12: as noted above it is not clear what you mean by open research and I can't go back to your first page to re-read your link. The risks might be that different countries  / institutions have very different approaches to training & processes such as ethics training and approval, and this can be challenging to manage.
Q3.12: I haven't looked for training because I was trained years ago, and i learn through reading and engaging with colleagues, students, conferences. Q4.12: I can't think of risks relating to data management except for the need to ensure anonymity if you are sharing data with a repository, and this is a massive task potentially
Q4.13: we don't have training per se on this I don't think but we are expected to include it in all grant applications - and we are supported through the sharing of successful data management plans
Q5.12: I have no idea what this refers to
Q6.12: barriers might be collaborators abroad may not have access to the same software as we do in the UK and so sharing data / analysis may be challenging, eg for researchers in places like Ethiopia
Q8.12: proper collaboration might involve working with a big team e.g. my current project has a team of around 12-15 who all have access to our google folder with all the data. There are risks of inadvertant deletion / tampering although I'm very confident of my team to not do this, one can never guarantee this won't happen.

Q11.13: I discuss this with my team quite often, and with colleagues, we try and have principles that we've derived through reading and thinking about these issues

Q5: Phase 3: Mid/Recognised (e.g., Senior Lecturer, Reader, Senior Researcher)
Q1.12: I do not see risk or barriers to my field of study from co-production.
Q1.13: Co-production is relevant to a number of research studies, but might not be appropriate to all. What would monitoring look like? And compliance would need monitoring co-production was made compulsory.
Q2.12: Ensuring compliance with legal requirements when conducting research that requires the collection of personal identifiable data is highly important. It requires constant updating of changes to law, guidelines and processes that need to be constantly checked for compliance.
Q3.12: It is challenging to think of ways to monitor transparent qualitative data practices. Sharing qualitative data for secondary studies (for example) brings about a series of complications that do not have a 'one size fits all' solution. In my view, encouraging researchers to be transparent in the way that research is designed, data are collected and reported (and shared if relevant) and findings are disseminated need to be the norm, regardless of the type of research conducted.
Q4.12: Poor data management presents high risks, but my research is followed by an ethics approval (or at a minimum, overseeing by colleagues experts in ethics). I have completed GCP training which highlights the importance of good research practice, and carry out GDPR or relevant training.  Raising awareness of the research community of consequences of poor data management is vital.
Q5.13: In my view, (pre)registration of studies is a practice that the research community are aware of, but it's not necessarily clear what the consequences are of not registering certain types of studies. Clinical trials for instance are highly monitored by funders or R&D departments, but this isn't the only type of study that could/must be registered. There is a need to 'close the loop' of registration by encouraging researchers to update their registered studies/projects after research has concluded.
Q6.12: I am not aware of risks or barriers to using open source software (other than being sure that the application/software is reliable).
Q6.13: Using open source in research will depend a lot on the field. I am not too familiar of the impact of open source use in research.
Q7.12: Creating open source software will be linked to the characteristics/field of the research being conducted. Software engineers and research engineers are quite active in this space and Southampton has an important community (software sustainability institute) who works in this area. But I am not aware of the implications of developing open source software to research activity overall.
Q8.12: Not knowing about version control in developing open source software is something that I don't know a lot about. I took training on this a while back, when I was involved in projects developing software, and the engineers I worked with were very strict about version control. I have used github in the past (and Southampton developed an instance of this internal to the university) and this type of repositories support version control as they embed this aspect of software development within the application. I do not know what challenges can arise from poor version control if the possibility of poor control may have been gone with the advent of good software repositories.
Q9.1: I am not aware of this
Q10.1: I am not aware of this
Q11.12: I think that poor guidelines for recognising the specific substantive contribution of everyone involved in a research project may have more risks to individuals than fields. Unless that is if a promising researcher is not recognised and as a result career becomes interrupted/stopped (the field would suffer but we wouldn't be able to know). The barriers to recognition are to do with a poor research culture that still promotes unfair practices which are not easily discoverable.
Q11.13: Approaches like CRediT should in time decrease the risks/barriers associated with poor recognising of contribution to research. Other initiatives, like the use of Narrative CVs or  Resume for Researchers (by the Royal Society) would in time have a positive effect in research culture.
Q12.12: There are risks in not declaring conflicts of interest, but I am confident in the way that my group/university recognises this and ensures appropriate behaviours in declaring CoIs when they exist.
Q13.12: Risks associated with preprints lie in the readiness of the findings being published and the potential misinterpretation by the public. A preprint must be a manuscript that is in a finished state, ready to be submitted to a journal. The purpose that preprint serves is not publishing unfinished or low-quality research, but ensuring that it reaches the scientific community much earlier than the usual journal publication process. Further, research published via the preprints route must then follow a journal publication.
Q16_11_TEXT: Open research practices is quite broad. I think this question should allow for more than one option to be selected. Other barriers are the low trust on open peer review (which is possible in preprints or other green access repositories) and a research culture that hasn't developed clear policies or guidelines on the open research practices that are encourange/allowed/mandated.

Phase 3: Mid/Recognised (e.g., Senior Lecturer, Reader, Senior Researcher)
Q1.13: By and large I'm not sure my field usually has stakeholders outside traditional researchers.
Q2.9: National training events, online webinars, MRC postdoctoral trainer programs.
Q2.12: My work is often collaborative with researchers outside my immediate area, and pushback from collaborators is not uncommon.
Q2.13: This has been pretty much at the centre of our disciplinary conversation since the Bermuda Principles in 1996. Open data and code sharing has been very much the disciplinary expectation for a fair while.
Q4.12: Research programms often evolve sufficiently rapidly that data management plans quickly become outdated. Often plans are made, but they are often not enforced.
Q4.13: Generally the ability to store data long term is lacking. Insitutional repositories exist, but often lack the capacity to store the required volume of data for the required length of time.
Q5.13: Research plans often evolve on a weekly or monthly basis. A reseracher might do 3 experiments in a week, all of which are dependent on the results of the previous experiment. Thus preregistration is unlikely to be relevant except in the case of the very largest studies aimed at testing an hypothesis. However, such studies are generally so expensive ($100m's) that it is rare that large data collection exercise set out to answer a specific hypothesis (or are undertaken in this country).
Q6.13: All of the software we use is open-source, but it is so ingrained into the field that no one thinks twice about it - its just the norm. The idea of paying for software is completely alien to the field.
Q7.12: As the maintianer of a widely used (within the field) software package, it is almost impossible to obtain resources to fund the maintaince and development. However, just keeping the package going, let alone developing it further requires significant effort (say 5-10% of an FTE).
Q7.13: I really do feel that funded resources to support existing packages is an important missing part of the landscape.
Q8.9: MRC postdoctoral training program (CGAT), Codecademy, coursera.
Q8.12: The amount of effort required to properly version control all analysis code and data products makes it difficult to convince trainees of the importance of doing this.
Q9.9: MRC postdoctoral traning program (CGAT), Coursera, webinars, journal tutorials.
Q9.12: There is a culture of "getting results", which often means there is pressure to cut exactly this sort of corner when things get difficult.
Q9.13: Researchers often start out with the best of intensions, but the longer a project goes on, and the more pressure is applied by funders/collaborators/faculty to produce results, the further we get from this ideal.
Q10.13: There is a lot of noise about FAIR at the university, but not much is actaully done. A recent series of videos about the advantages were very nicely produced, but I suspect very few people saw them.
Q11.12: Research is often collaborative, and the collaborators often don't understand the level of contribution from those outside their expertise.
Q11.13: Sometimes risks have to be taken. Its all very well taking risks for yourself, but as a PI, when you make decisions, you are taking a risk with your trainees futures.
Q13.13: I always post any reserach I am lead author for as a preprint, but as much of the work I do is collaborative, it often depends on the willingness of collaborators, which is not always present.
Q14.12: Publishing OA can be expensive if you don't have access to funds (eg if the research is not UKRI funded).
Q16: Lack of mandates from funders, institutions or regulators

Q1.9: NHS, AHSN etc. who support researchers with PPI training
Q1.12: Both funding and research ethics in NHS require evidence of PPI. Lack of training in this area could be a barrier for ECRs unless working with experienced researchers
Q1.13: For a lot of research involving interventions and innovation in care PPI and co-design is expected. But there is wide range of quality in these activities. Only some research projects obtain the potential benefits of co-design and good PPI
Q2.12: There are barriers are openness when working with legacy data - for which even anonymised sharing was not part of the original consent.
Q3.12: There are none that I can think of immediately.
Q3.13: I know of the relevant network in my institution but, I am not sure if there is cut through to the majority of qualitative researchers as yet.
Q4.12: The biggest challenge around data are conflicting interpretations by ethics committee and similar around some of the types of data I am involved in collecting. For instance, recordings of people speaking which are/are not considered anonymous if the content includes not identifying information
Q5.12: This is not big among the community I work in, but is growing. No apparent barriers or risks that I can perceive.
Q7.12: Some health-related fields have been slow to adopt open science methods. However, I have long relied on open source software and don't think it poses any risks to our research.
Q8.12: I've been using version control for many years, but can see that for others there are barriers training is not available but this is not the case at my institution.
Q10.12: The institution has good support for data management and sharing. However, I have not accessed training in much depth. There might well be barriers for people without technical knowledge on RDM etc.
Q11.12: I'm afraid I can't really comment as I haven't had much experience in this area at all.
Q12.12: Again this is difficult to comment on. Usually these terms are dictated by external bodies (funders, publishers etc).
Q13.13: Within my research area this has not yet really become a regular activity. But is ones I hope to see happening much more regularly.
Q14.13: Ref and funders drive this in my institution.

Q4: Lecturer in Early Modern British History
Q5: Phase 2: Early (e.g., Research Associate, first grant holder, Lecturer)
Phase 2: Early (e.g., Research Associate, first grant holder, Lecturer)
Q2.13: I very rarely do research involving human particpants. Thus, data protection and GDPR is rarely an issue for me. Although carrying out research in line with legal and ethical practices is, of course, of paramount importance, the vast majority of research I do does not throw up any such issues as defined by the linked document on GDPR...
Q3.13: I have thus far carried out very little qualitative research, however I am interested in carrying out more and may look into this in the future.
Q4.13: In computer science, it is common practice and usually very easy to make artifacts available. Many publication venues encourage and/or mandate this. I here assume "for me, training is important" means "I need training on this" rather than "I think people should be trained on this". I have therefore made it of medium importance, since I largely feel I have already received sufficient training for my day to day needs.
Q5.13: I do not think this is particularly important in computer science research since it is so easy to make software artifacts and data available as part of research publications. It is therefore less important to preregister plans for study.
Q6.13: As before, I assume "for me, training in this topic is" represents my personal need for training. In computer science, using open source software such as python, numpy, etc. is standard practice
Q7.13: This is generally standard practice in computer science research, with many publication venues encouraging/requiring that software artefacts be made available.
Q8.13: I use this as a matter of course. I would personally find it helpful for collaborations if others did the same.
Q9.13: I would like my institution to provide a training module specifically on containerisation, such as Docker, to maximise reproducability.
Q11.13: I know my institution provides guidelines for what qualifies for authorship on papers, but these must be flexible, especially for collaborations. In general, I feel further guidelines on this would be helpful, although I am more interested in collaborating with people than I am in reading or writing statements on who did what on every publication. However, I can see that recording specific contrbutions may be useful for performance reviews and disputes.
Q12.13: To me, this follows from ethical research. All publication venues I have used have an option to do this and usually provide sufficiently clear guidelines on what counts as a conflict of interest. These are usually fairly consistent between venues.
Q14.12: Many publishing companies require additional payment to make research articles open access.
Q14.13: Many funding organisations (including my current grant funder) require this. On the basis that much of research is funded by the taxpayer, I feel we have a moral obligation to make all such work freely available. I see the current system of private publshing companies requiring payment to view published articles as morally reprehensible.

Q1.12: It needs to be more central to what we do, I research education and various student factors yet I find it very hard to get the support to play students as co-creators of this information.
Q1.13: This is vital in so many areas including mine, however it's not something that many academics seem to want to incorporate in their research particularly in the educational field, we need evidence-based research and individuals to support this.
Q2.12: Ethics are very important, and are taken seriously by the Department, however there are other departments within the University that don't see this as central to their research and this means that insufficient care is taken when designing studies and recruiting participants more could be done to address this in terms of  good research design.
Q2.13: More education is needed on this topic however it should be in the form of ongoing debate and discussion. Currently the workplace training is that of a tick box exercise conducted online which is neither interesting nor revealing.
Q3.12: Researchers very much tend to fall into either a qualitative or quantitative researchers with very few using mixed methods, mixed methods are valuable because they allow us to explore a topic in more than one way which provides a richness of data and overall better quality information as a result unfortunately many researchers from either tradition are reluctant to incorporate mixed methods in their studies and often journals will suggest that one element is From the article for a simpler presentation.
Q3.13: I believe that the qualitative/quantitative divide begins at undergraduate level with students deciding which they prefer and not pursuing the other. Ideally we would teach and model mixed methods from the start and discourage students from viewing themselves as qualitative or qualitative but rather to appreciate how this plan be incorporated in different topics.
Q4.12: Not really, it's something that's briefly covered as part of ethics but otherwise not really discussed in my area
Q5.12: I think pre-registering is a really good idea, however unfortunately in a lot of cases in the area these are simply not followed up (for various reasons such as not completing the study or non-significant findings. I would like to see this utilised more
Q5.13: It would be good if there were a central place to upload all preregistration
Q6.7_8_TEXT: Are a few people who do this but in limited and not quite tailored for what we use it for
Q6.9: Another university I work at â can't comment on this as it's coming up in a few weeks.
Q6.12: There is still a reliance on expensive proprietary software which disadvantages the students who learn to use something they may not use in the future (e.g. SPSS)
Q6.13: This is something that would be good for serious staff members to model and the University to promote and subscribe to.
Q7.12: This is definitely the way of the future, however I lack the skills to do this and the time needed to become proficient in doing this.
Q7.13: Again this would be something that would be massively helped by free training and support.
Q8.12: I do a simplistic version of this in my own work and offer students advice to do the same.
Q8.13: This is really helpful as a good research practice, I do this on a simplistic basis that more could be to do this regularly.
Q9.12: Not really something that occurs in my field but would be worthwhile investigating
Q9.13: I don't know enough to comment but it would be good for this to be included in journal articles as a footnote
Q10.12: All research should be conducted in this way and the University should provide support and training to ensure that it is. They do to a limited degree the support this but it should be much more vigourously done
Q11.12: The difficulty with this is that those that provide limited support do not have anywhere between an acknowledgement and an author credit.
Q11.13: It would be useful if you could have A category contribution, for example when I started my PhD I was told to name a supervisor as first author even though they did no work on that paper, equally I have disabilities that mean I need to use specialist software and occasionally papers need a lot of editing as a result, I have a research assistant who I always credit in the acknowledgements but I feel it would be helpful to have a way of distinguishing her from someone who has perhaps helped the project in a limited way but not actually made a big contribution.
Q12.12: Personally this is not relevant as the researcher I do relate to university students and this means that I don't have a conflict of interest in the same way a grant funded researcher would.
Q12.13: I would like to see more of this on papers, including an acknowledgement where paper costs are funded or self paid.
Q13.12: My field does not particularly do this, as an individual researcher I would like to register preprints that I'm often not given the opportunity to do so
Q13.13: It would be useful if more organisations in this
Q14.12: The University does fund some open access papers, but this is not often done and many journals I have submitted to do not subscribe to this and insist that your data is not shared elsewhere as a condition of publishing.
Q14.13: I would like to see much more open acess across research, this strengthens everyone. More open access should also be devoted to nonsignificant studies as these are rarely accepted for publication that often have a lot to tell us.

Q2.13: Have had issues when designing a qualitative study  - do we make findings accessible/open e.g. on ORDA but might be sensitive data and would any one else really want it without first contacting us it is so context dependent. But, of course, having a plan which may need to be adjusted is very different from making it up as you go along.

Q1.13: Despite the importance of my research (MRSA) for clinicians, there is very little collaboration between clinicians and researchers (I think because often these groups talk in such different languages! E.g., clinicans know very little about molecular mechanisms, researchers know very little about real-life drugs/patient outcomes.
Q2.13: This topic is highly relevant to my research as I use human blood samples- therefore knowledge of the Human Tissue Act is essential. Health and safety officers in my old department (Medical School) were able to advise on training but this training was external (i.e., the MRC website) and within my new department (Biosciences) there is no guidance on HTA compliance (presumably because so few people use human tissue).
Q3.13: Qualitative data is not collected in my field of study and qualitative data that is collected (e.g., images of experimental output) is used as supplementary material, not proof of a result.
Q4.7_8_TEXT: Good for students, not so great for staff members- I did data management training during my PhD but I'm not sure how I would access this material now.
Q4.13: My line manager monitors my data management practices but there is not a departmental wide approach to this (at least not for staff members).
Q5.12: Preregistration would be very high risk for my field of study- if protocols were disseminated/aims shared with other groups, its likely that a bigger, wealthier lab would use these protocols to publish papers on the topics before us.
Q5.13: Not important (and actually highly discouraged) in research field.
Q6.9: Online tutorials and training courses hosted by other Universities.
Q6.13: Highly important for my research, however knowledge of how to use open source software varies drastically between groups (e.g., I would never ask my own line manager for help with this because our group does very little code based analysis but I know of other colleagues that can help me).

Q7.13: More training during early research (e.g., as an undergraduate or PhD student) would be highly beneficial.

Q2.7: I do not know,Other. Please explain:
Q2.7_8_TEXT: I have not yet done training, though it does seem to be available. I'm pretty skilled already in publishing OA, ensuring my work including all data is already shared online in citable OA formats so I haven't pursued training.
Q2.12: Occasionally in archaeology we have to be careful with sharing data on living humans (e.g. ethnoarchaeology, experimental studies), and these data cannot be shared OA.
Q2.13: I think even more funding for OA options would be great. There are still funding barriers (conditions) to publishing OA in the 'best' journals, especially for work that was not UKRI funded (plenty isn't!). This shouldn't be a barrier to sharing our research widely.
Q4.12: If the institution takes a monitoring & compliance approach to this, I'm unaware of that as I'm relatively new to the institution.
Q4.13: This is very important to my research, and as I manage my own project, it can be sometimes challenging to remember this significance. I try to consistently remind myself of the data management plan I have in place.
Q5.12: Archaeology tends to be a field where you can't really predict findings ahead of time.
Q5.13: Pre-registering reports for archaeology feels an unnecessary additional step. It doesn't really align with the type of work we do in my opinion, and does not seem to be common practice.
Q6.9: University College London, other online training courses, YouTube, etc
Q6.12: Not being able to be trained in open software is actually really problematic. As an example, training in R which is open source statistics package, and rather difficult to learn, would be very useful for me. However, there is only just this month a short trial including some online courses in R, being offered by the university. These are the courses that would be most useful for me, rather than many of the professional development courses regularly on offer.
Q6.13: Please make online and in person training in open software packages (e.g. R, QGIS, GIMP) regularly available to researchers.
Q7.13: There are probably some areas in archaeology where this is important (e.g. modelling) but broadly speaking developing software probably isn't a high priority.
Q9.12: Seems to be a lack of availabilty of training
Q10.12: There seems to be basic training in FAIR principles (i.e. an introduction to what it means) as part of training modules. But beyond that I am not sure to what extent the university is providing training to develop this within research projects or to ensure it is occurring.
Q12.13: Not especially relevant in archaeology as a discipline.
Q13.13: I have used preprints to make research OA which would not otherwise be easily searchable and accessible. I have also used it in an instance where I want the work to be available and citable, but also to be able to continue to evolve over the next few years - this has proved very useful!

Q14.12: Open access is currently monetised by private companies, which overcharge for publishing articles in open access.  This is a lucrative business that leads to significant research funding going to those companies.
Q14.13: Universities and research institution have to seriously start looking at the business models of publishers.   Using public research funding to pay up to 8000 GBP for publishing in open access base, see for example here https://www.nature.com/nature-portfolio/open-access, is ethically not justified.    Note that there exist journals such as SciPost Physics https://scipost.org/about#GOA and quantum https://quantum-journal.org/about/ that do not charge for publishing in open access.   These true open access journals should be more supported by public research institutions.
